TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, will be absent from the chamber today. Senator Bolkus is travelling back from overseas. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Bolkus in relation to his portfolio and those he represents should be directed to Senator Robert Ray.

—Will the Minister representing the Minister for Finance inform the Senate whether the level and composition of spending by any department will be exempt from examination by the Expenditure Review Committee in the lead-up to the forthcoming Budget?
—No department will be exempt.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the Minister's answer. I also note that the Minister for Social Security has said that he will ensure that there are no further spending cuts in his portfolio but that the Minister for Finance has declared that no department will be sealed off from the review process. Who is right?

—The question which Senator Short originally asked me was: will any department be exempt from examination? The answer to that question is no. The answer to the question of whether any department will be exempt will depend on the outcome of the Expenditure Review Committee process, but that is yet to be determined. If the honourable senator does not understand that, I will say it again for him.

—Senator Hill is correcting my syntax. I find that extraordinarily offensive. In answer to Senator Short's original question, I said that no department will be exempt from examination. That answer stands. What the examination will decide is a matter to be determined.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In view of the recent collapse of the Ethiopian Government, can the Minister give details of, firstly, prospects for a peaceful settlement between the various forces within Ethiopia; secondly, whether Australia's humanitarian aid program to Ethiopia has been or is affected by the fighting or by the collapse of the Ethiopian central Government; and, thirdly, the Government's attitude to proposals to hold a plebiscite to determine the future relationship between Eritrea and the rest of Ethiopia? Will the Eritreans be granted full independence or some other confederate or autonomous form of government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the resignation and flight of President Mengistu last week, fighting in the north and north-west of the country has seen significant gains made by the various rebel groups in Eritrea. The Eritrean People's Liberation Front has at last captured Asmara and the strategic port of Assab while the Tigrean People's Liberation Front has now surrounded the capital, Addis Ababa.

ANSWER.PARA: The prospects for a peaceful settlement now rest with the round table meeting, which began in London yesterday, between the Government and rebel groups. There have been very recent reports, not yet confirmed, that a cease-fire has in fact been agreed upon at the conference.

The Australian Government has long supported and called for a negotiated settlement of the conflict in Ethiopia. We have made this very clear to the Ethiopian Government and to the various rebel groups. We are certainly hopeful that the London talks will see the end of a conflict which has gone on for 30 years and which has contributed so much to the tragedy of Ethiopia during that period.

As to the second part of the question, the bulk of the Australian Government's humanitarian assistance to Ethiopia, which has totalled $11.4m this financial year, has been channelled through Australian non-government organisations working with local relief agencies. The Australian NGOs are: Community Aid Abroad (CAA); Australian Freedom From Hunger Campaign; Australian Catholic Relief; Australian Council of Churches; World Vision Australia; Austcare and the Lutheran World Service.

All agencies-and I understand that this is true of the other international ones as well-advise that their operations are continuing, albeit after making appropriate alterations to their programs in keeping with the changing situation.

While a media report has suggested that Community Aid Abroad is concerned about two of its employees, of whom it has not heard since the weekend, CAA has assured the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau that there is no reason to fear for their safety.

As to the last part of Senator Schacht's question, there have been reports that a plebiscite or referendum under international supervision will be held to determine the future relationship between Eritrea and the rest of the country. That is certainly something that the Eritreans have been seeking for a long time. The Australian Government's view on that is essentially that this is a question for the Ethiopian people to decide and we will respect any decision made as the end result of a genuinely democratic process.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MINISTER FOR SOCIAL SECURITY: OVERSEAS TRIPS

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Social Security to stories in this morning's Canberra Times, Telegraph Mirror, West Australian, Adelaide Advertiser, and Brisbane Courier-Mail which all express amazement at the nature, extent and cost of the Minister's three European trips in the last seven months. Can the Minister inform the Senate whether his idea of social justice includes spending over $2,000 for a two-night stay in a London hotel; almost $4,500 on a three-day chauffeur-driven limousine trip around the west coast of Ireland; and a $630 bill for food, drink and other living expenses for one night in Hong Kong-all this at the same time as almost 40,000 Australians joined the dole queues in January?
—Tell us about it, Richo.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to; that is precisely what I am going to do. The reason that these newspapers showed such interest in this event is that Senator Alston issued a press release and sent it out to them. The newspapers looked at what Senator Alston had showed them and reacted accordingly. Newspapers will always react to overseas trips by Ministers in that way. But Senator Alston in his press release did not tell the whole truth, which I shall do now.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Alston asked some specific questions and I will answer those first and then seek to give a more general answer. I have not yet received the bill for a two-night stay in a hotel in London. I have received no bills at all for the January trip or for the April trip, and it was only last week that I received bills for the trip in September. The reason for that is that it always takes some time for these things to come through.

TALK.START.PARA: —Four or five months?

—That is normal. As I said, I have not received the January bill yet; I do not know when I will receive it. The Department of Administrative Services knows that I will not be leaving town for a while; the Department will find me. I do leave town occasionally; I go to and from the Labor State of New South Wales.

ANSWER.PARA: As for the $2,000 bill, I stayed in exactly the same room on a previous trip and the cost was less than $500 a night, so when I receive these bills-and I am sure that will happen soon-I will seek to find out why I have been charged more for the same room. If there is not a good enough reason for being charged more, quite obviously I will seek some recompense from the hotel concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much did you actually sign for?

—I will get to all of this-just be calm. As far as the $4,000 for three days in Ireland is concerned, it was six days. The $4,000 was for car hire. The Irish Government set up talks on the west coast of Ireland; I did not want to walk from the east coast, so we drove.
—It would have done you a bit of good.

—It would have been a long walk and it probably would have made me a little bit fitter but I decided to drive. In respect of the drive, the car hire for that in Ireland and for the whole lot was not for me but, rather, for six people. On each trip--
—Why couldn't you have done it in Dublin?

—Let me get this out so that it is exact. On the first and second trips-the second trip was the Ireland one-I was accompanied by my wife and by a staff member. As well as that, the Secretary of my Department, his wife and a senior departmental official were on both of those trips. So there were six people-not just me-and it is very hard to fit six people into one car, especially when they are as big as some of the people who were on this trip are. We did not have one car, we had two. I do not think I will ever be able to provide a breakdown to honourable senators as to who was in what car at what time. I do not think we have kept a record of that, so that is something Opposition senators will have to learn to live without.

ANSWER.PARA: In so far as the one bill for food quoted at $630 is concerned-which was not for one day but for two, but that does not matter; I concede it is still a lot of money-the ridiculous part of this is that I have not had any opportunity to go through any of these bills to see what it is appropriate that I return to the taxpayer. I will. I have not yet and I will not for some time because, as I have explained, I have not even received them. But I will go through them and, at the end, I will see what I should pay back and will do so. It must be noted, of course, that whenever any Minister stays in a hotel the bills are picked up by the embassies. The embassies send the bills back to Australia later. The Ministers go through the bills and, where the Ministers consider it appropriate to send money back, we do-and I shall.

In so far as what was left out this morning is concerned, if we are looking at the bottom line for trips, I would have thought that signing an agreement with the Netherlands Government in January which saves Australia $7m a year was worth the $50,000 spent on the trip. If I can do that for every trip I go on, then I think the Australian taxpayer will be well served indeed. I might say that as far as the last trip is concerned, it was even better because whereas Germany had stalled on negotiations with us and refused to continue, I got the agreement of the German Government not just to continue but to conclude an agreement within 12 months, which will save Australia $20m a year and will bring into the country $60m a year. So that is what I was doing there and I am glad I went.

The only problem with the second and third trips, frankly, is that Saddam Hussein got in the road and made it two instead of one. I was to visit Germany and Portugal on the last trip but could not do so because there was a war and the Parliament was recalled. I think all honourable senators will remember coming back from wherever they were in January. I was in Italy and I came back from Italy when the Parliament was recalled and could not continue on to Germany.

TALK.START.PARA: —Salerno.
—That is right, I was in Salerno. Why was I there? I was there because I went down to the south of Italy--
—Did you go to Plati?

—No, I did not. I went to the south of Italy to enable me to go to Avellino and Benevento. These are places where the Australian Government allocated the enormous sums of money raised during the Italian earthquake some years ago. I visited a hospital which was set up with Australian money, and I visited an old persons home which we had renovated with Australian money. I had been requested to do so for a long, long time and I finally got there. As to whether that is a bad thing or not, Senator Alston can ask those in the Italian community; I will leave it up to them, but I have not had any complaints about the fact that I went and saw where millions of Australian dollars had been spent.

ANSWER.PARA: I did not get to Germany and Portugal. That meant, of course, that instead of the domestic air fares within Europe to get to those countries, I came back to Australia and then had to spend the money to go back. Not to pursue with countries like Germany those agreements that will save millions of dollars for Australia would mean I was not doing my job. I will always do it. I went back and did it and, I might say, given the progress with Austria, I might have to go back there as well because it will save Australia a few more millions. I will do it every single time. But Senator Alston did not include that in his press release-he never does. He only tells half the story and, as always, the half story is wrong anyway.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am fascinated to learn that there is so much wrong with the official information provided to me through the Estimates committee system. Would Senator Richardson please explain whether this information was supplied by the Department of Administrative Services (DAS) through his competent colleague Senator Bolkus?
—I will get some figures for Snedden and we will see how you like that.

—In due course. Was that then provided to Senator Richardson's office and did he vet it before he made it available to me? In other words, who is responsible for ensuring the accuracy of this information? Can Senator Richardson also tell me whether he has repaid anything in respect of the first September trip so we can get some idea of what his intentions might have been before this publicity arose?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I told Senator Alston that his inaccuracy was in leaving out what he knew to be true, which was the millions of dollars saved for Australia by the signing of these agreements.

—Oh, Mr President, all Opposition senators know that. I know that Senator Short is a bit thick, but even he could have surely worked that out. Naturally enough, Senator Alston left that information out because it did not make the story look as good. I do not dispute the accuracy of the information bar two points: firstly, there is a $2,000 discrepancy on one trip in the adding up of all the figures to get the total. I do not understand that yet and I will ask why. The second one is the phone calls, which Senator Alston has already acknowledged in today's question. His press release said it was phone calls. The information given to Senator Alston was wrong because it was not phone calls but car hire.

ANSWER.PARA: The information that DAS was sending out to Senator Alston was--

TALK.START.PARA: —Whose fault was that-Bolkus's?
—Order! Senator Alston, you have asked your question.

—The totals given to Senator Alston by the Department of Administrative Services were given to me. The answer that he got was given to me. I did not vet it because this is not the sort of information that one vets; one gets it, but does not vet it. I did not start taking out anything; I simply got it for notification.

ANSWER.PARA: In his supplementary question, Senator Alston asked how much money I have paid back for the September trip. I said that I received the bills for the September trip last week. I have not even looked at them yet. I will not this week either-I am busy-but over the next few weeks I will. When I have looked at them, I will pay back whatever I think I owe.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week? Eight months.
—I got them last week.
—Order! There are too many interjections.

—I cannot possibly be expected to go through bills to the certification stage when I have not got them. But I now have them and so my job is to certify those bills to see what is correct and what is not, and to query them where I consider them to be wrong. I shall do so.
—And advise the Senate accordingly.

—I am happy to advise the Senate of whatever I do. Given that I have not had the opportunity to do it, I wonder how I can be expected to have done so. At the end of the day, as has always been the case with my trips, I will make sure that it is not me who is in debt. I always make sure that I pay back more than I consider I have to.

ANSWER.PARA: The best example of that was my trip to Brazil and America some years back. I paid a couple of thousand dollars for my wife's bills when I returned to Australia because the Senate was recalled and the Opposition had cancelled pairs. Rather than bring her back to Australia on the plane and then take her back to America on the taxpayer, which I was entitled to do, I did not do that. I left her in New York and paid the bills, which I did not have to anyway. I will always do that to make sure that I do not charge the taxpayer too much.

At some point, I would like Senator Alston to explain how, in the press release he issued, there was this great attack on my colleague Con Sciacca for leading a parliamentary delegation that had nothing to do with social security and was attended by three members of the coalition. Why did he leave that information out?

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Industrial Relations seen reports of complaints by Mr Ian Spicer, the Chief Executive of the Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI), about the Government's reaction to the recent national wage case decision? Am I right in assuming that Mr Spicer is claiming, in effect, that the parties are legally bound by this decision and claiming that the Government is attempting unconstitutionally to assume the national wage fixing role? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether Mr Spicer's complaints about the Government's wages policy are correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw a letter from Mr Ian Spicer in the Australian Financial Review last week, to which I have replied-just so the record is kept straight. Mr Spicer has made allegations of that sort directly to me. It is appropriate that the record be set straight. I think Mr Spicer knows better. He is a qualified lawyer in his own right-he understands the industrial law-and would understand that the allegations he has made are not true. It seems that it is part of a public debate in which there is an interest in confusing or bluffing people with legal jargon.

ANSWER.PARA: Essentially, there have been three assertions made: that the Government, by not accepting the Industrial Relations Commission's wage case decision, has established a precedent which implies that any decision of the IRC can be rejected; that it follows that employers could, with impunity, ignore awards if employers do not agree with the IRC decisions; and that the Government is acting unconstitutionally by attempting to fix wages. All of those allegations are incorrect.

The situation is that the Government did criticise-and we do not resile from it-the national wage case decision. We endorsed the institution of the Industrial Relations Commission and reaffirmed its role; but we reserve the right to criticise this decision, which does not endorse the accord. The Industrial Relations Commission's decision in national wage cases is not a decision from which an order of the Commission emanates; that is, an order making or varying an award and thus creating law. With the order, the Industrial Relations Commission issues a new law. That law must be obeyed by the parties bound by it. This Government obeys all such laws and advices and counsels employers and workers to do likewise.

In the national wage case, the IRC made a decision; it did not issue an order. It issued an invitation to unions to apply for a 2.5 per cent wage increase on the basis that they give a voluntary commitment to continue award restructuring, to file no further claims, and to produce further productivity changes in industry for an open-ended period. To my knowledge, only three unions have applied. Those are the Northern Territory Senior Police Officers Association, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Senior Executive Staff Officers Association, and the Australian Federation of Air Pilots. All those unions cover senior executives or highly paid personnel and would benefit more from a 2.5 per cent variation to their rates of pay than a $12 flat increase.

The decision was made some six weeks ago and no other unions, to my knowledge, have applied. Instead, they have sought to negotiate directly with employers. The Australian Government has entered those negotiations and concluded an agreement which it would like the Commission, at some stage, to vary our awards for but which we will observe. In that case, if we do, there is no unconstitutional act applying. If the allegation that Mr Spicer is making is that we have not applied to impose the 2.5 per cent increase, the allegation can equally be made to all the members of Mr Spicer's organisation-the CAI-which has, likewise, not applied for the Commission's decision to be entered into awards. The CAI may not have done that for exactly the same reason as the Government-that is, this is still a free society: one cannot compel an independent party to give a voluntary commitment to observe a set of criteria, which the national wage case decision in this case required it to do. Thus it is that no major employer organisation in this country has applied to impose a 2.5 per cent wage increase on its employees.

The final point I make in regard to whether the Government is acting unconstitutionally is that, clearly, that is a ridiculous assertion. If we are doing so, I invite Mr Spicer to take legal action against us. The fact that he has not and continues to make the allegation suggests that I am right and that there is no legal case. Of course, there is not. The allegation seems to be that we negotiated with our own work force-which is the privilege of any employer. If that is the allegation, the Government is guilty and I am pleased to be guilty of that. We have now reached an arrangement with our work force for a wages and productivity package to be struck, which means that wages in Australian government employment can rise but the costs of delivering the services that the Australian public sector provides can be reduced.

That seems to me to be the total essence of productivity bargaining. That is an outcome that is devoutly to be wished for in the private sector as well. I think these allegations should be seen for what they are: an attempt at point-scoring and bluster, rather than any real legal analysis.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. The question concerns Jervis Bay and is in three parts. What action will the Minister take in response to the actions of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel in failing to consult the Australian Heritage Commission, failing to conduct an environmental impact assessment and overruling the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Australian Capital Territory Parks and Conservation Bureau, before proceeding with last week's Army exercise on National Estate areas at Jervis Bay, which was called off after unacceptable environmental damage was caused? Does the Minister accept that the circumstances surrounding this exercise suggest a lack of Government commitment to protecting Jervis Bay, especially in the light of last January's fire on Beecroft Peninsula, which was caused by a Royal Australian Navy bombardment exercise and burnt out 1,200 hectares, and the total absence of environmental provisions in the draft management strategy plan for Jervis Bay of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories? Has the Government abandoned yet another environmental promise made before last year's Federal election promise, namely, to protect Jervis Bay waters and surrounding land areas and catchments via a national park?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Included in Senator Coulter's question are a number of assumptions that I will dispute, but it will be necessary to get some more information to him. I can answer the questions in part. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories approved the Army conducting a logistics exercise named Termite Spray 91 at Murrays Beach in the Jervis Bay Territory during May of this year, subject to the Army complying with strict conditions protecting the environment, health and safety. The ACT Parks and Conservation Bureau is under contract to the Minister's Department to provide land management services in the Jervis Bay Territory. The Bureau's views were included in the Department's advice to the Minister and were considered in reaching the decision to approve the Army exercise in the Territory. The Bureau was closely involved in formulating the conditions which were agreed to by the Army concerning the conduct of the Murrays Beach operation.

ANSWER.PARA: Because of the strict conditions agreed to by the Army, because there was adequate access to the beach via an existing fire trail, because no new works or vegetation removal were required, and because there was no expectation of significant impact on the environment, action under the Australian Heritage Commission Act was not required, although regard was had to some of its provisions. Activities at Murrays Beach were closely monitored by the Department and its land management agent, the ACT Parks and Conservation Bureau.

Contrary to reports in the media, there were no more than 20 soldiers in the Murrays Beach area at any one time, nor were tanks involved or tracks hacked through the bush. But because of heavy rain, the Army was required by the Department to conclude the exercise at Murrays Beach about six hours early. The exercise finished at about 6 p.m. on 23 May without apparent significant impact on the environment. In accordance with its undertaking, the Army will level the surface of the fire trail as soon as the weather permits. Overall, the trail will be in better condition than it was before the Army exercise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I would have thought that it would be fairly easy for the Minister to answer the last part of the question. The Government made a promise before the last election in relation to Jervis Bay. I repeat: has the Government abandoned yet another environmental promise made before last year's Federal election, namely, to protect Jervis Bay waters and surrounding land areas and catchments via a national park?

—I did not answer that part of the question because it was not included in the brief supplied to me. I shall find out from the Minister where the Government is up to in discussing the appropriate protection that ought to be put in place for Jervis Bay. I just do not know the answer. I have not been the Minister responsible for the environment for 12 months, and I have not been involved in discussions with Senator Robert Ray or anybody else on this matter. I will find out where we are up to and let Senator Coulter know tomorrow.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. With reference to the air crash in Thailand on Sunday, which cost the lives of 223 people, I ask the Minister: what measures are in place to protect Australians flying into Bangkok?

—The Government, through its safety agencies, is actively monitoring the information that is being gained from the investigation at the aircraft crash site. We are doing this in close consultation with Qantas Airways Ltd, which now has a number of its officers in Bangkok reviewing safety procedures of Qantas's own operations through Bangkok. These operations are being closely monitored, including the use by Qantas of uniformed security guards. The level of protection being provided by Qantas security, in line with accepted international procedures, is considered to be the responsible level to provide at this time. For obvious reasons, I am not in a position to give any further detail on the security measures. It is far too early to speculate even on the cause of the crash itself. It may be some time before that is known with any certainty.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and follows a question from my colleague Senator Watson some weeks ago regarding Austrade's staff reductions proposed for Tasmania. Is the Minister aware of statements by a senior Westpac Banking Corporation economist, who suggested that Tasmania's unique new small export industries could help Tasmania to lead the rest of the country out of this recession that we had to have? Given the grave concern expressed by so many small export businesses in Tasmania, has the Minister reconsidered or recommended any changes to the proposed cutbacks to Austrade in Tasmania?

—I have not seen the view of a Westpac economist which postulates a Tasmanian-led recovery from the recession. But that economist belongs to a bank which could make a substantial contribution to recovery for many businesses if policies were not adopted of recalling debt irrespective of the payment performance of various companies. That is, of course, a gratuitous observation in passing.
—Absolutely.

—It is, absolutely. It is about time Senator Short faced up to it, because it is true. With regard to the Austrade posts in Tasmania, I had a discussion with the Chairman of Austrade about that issue last week. While I cannot announce at the present time any final position on that matter, Senator Calvert ought to be reassured that the proposal as it was first mooted is unlikely to be adopted in that form.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INFORMAL VOTES IN NEW SOUTH WALES ELECTION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Is the Minister aware of widespread problems experienced by voters at the New South Wales general election held last Saturday, resulting in the recording of informal votes which, at times, approached 18 per cent of those cast in some seats and totalled some 250,000 votes overall? Will the Minister seek a report from the Australian Electoral Commission on the nature of the problems encountered so as to avoid a repetition of this appalling situation at a national level?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —When any election is held around Australia, it is the normal practice for members of the Australian Electoral Commission, including from interstate, to go in as observers so that they can examine how the election is run, learn from any mistakes and also learn from any innovations that could be applied in their own State. I am quite sure that the Australian Electoral Commission would have been involved as an observer in every aspect of the New South Wales election.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that the informal vote in some electorates reached fairly remarkable heights-I think 20 per cent in two electorates. Almost certainly, this comes down to the fact that the Electoral Act was changed in New South Wales, I think, last November. If there is one thing that has come through to anyone who studies electoral systems, it is that if a system is changed a much higher informal vote is likely at the next poll.

In 1984, we learned that changing the Senate electoral system to requiring a `1' for a group vote had quite a substantial impact on the House of Representatives. It did not change the result in one seat, but it added to the informal vote. The conclusion we can draw is that if we continually change voting systems the informal vote will remain high.

There is a bit of a tradition in New South Wales of changing voting systems according to the self-interest of parties. There is no doubt that ticks and crosses were eliminated in November last year to help the coalition. The reduction in the number of seats and a redistribution were for the same reason. It was all supposed to add to the overwhelming return of the Greiner Government and the start of the Liberal resurgence in Australia. Well, it is back to the drawing board there.

In answer to Senator Loosley, I do not know whether we at the Federal level have to draw conclusions, other than that we should not be constantly tampering with the voting system and that we must be very conscious before each election of trying to sell how to vote formally. The philosophy of the Australian Electoral Commission adopted in 1983-easy to enrol, easy to vote-has stood us in very good stead. Honourable senators will note that in the 1987 and 1990 Federal elections informal votes were basically on the decline.

I do not know that anything can be done about the matter, other than to regret the fact that 250,000 citizens-probably 7 or 8 per cent of those entitled to vote-did not have their vote recorded properly on Saturday and at least half, and probably more, inadvertently voted informally. One must concede that there are always a few per cent of people who will vote informally deliberately. However, all that allowing ticks and crosses-or ticks, in particular-for two out of the three ballots, and denying it in the other, leads to is confusion and disfranchisement.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to recent reports in the Brisbane Courier-Mail that agencies providing emergency accommodation in Brisbane are being stretched to the limit, with increasing numbers of people from rural areas coming into the city to look for work? Is the Minister also aware that in provincial towns the situation is even more desperate, with people arriving in the towns looking for work, having spent all their money to get there, and then finding that they have no work, no money and nowhere to live? I also refer the Minister to comments made by the Queensland Premier, Mr Goss, that this was mostly a Commonwealth responsibility. As current programs for rural assistance focus more on those who still have farms, what forms of emergency measures can the Government provide in the guise of emergency housing or other such assistance to help these desperate workers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will endeavour to answer the question as best as I can. Of course, I am not responsible for housing-that comes within Minister Howe's portfolio-but, given that there is some crossover of interest, I shall do my best.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been asked about complaints in the Brisbane Courier-Mail that finding accommodation is very difficult for those moving into the cities or provincial towns as a result of the recession and, of course, the rural downturn. The rural downturn has causes which go way beyond those of the recession. I am not certain what Mr Kerin's view is as to how long it might last but, clearly, while it does there will be severe inconvenience.

The Commonwealth has not been in the business of providing emergency housing. That has always been a matter for the States. The Federal Government has, however, through a number of programs, funded the States to provide that housing. At the moment, Minister Howe has under way a complete review of the housing strategy in Australia and, as I understand it, he will be putting up to Cabinet a range of new measures in the Budget discussions this year. I am not yet certain how far they will go towards easing this problem. Clearly, we have to reach a situation where the Commonwealth and the States stop arguing about who is responsible-not just for the people to whom Senator Bjelke-Petersen referred, but also homeless kids and others-and make sure that someone is responsible and that that responsibility is lived up to.

I am not sure that either the States or the Commonwealth have ever lived up to their responsibilities in relation to accommodation for the poor and the disadvantaged before. I hope that, as a result of the initiatives we are taking in the Budget this time and with the States, by November we will at least be able to sort out the mess and start providing the accommodation that we always should have provided, at both State and Commonwealth levels.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Defence whether he has seen comments by an honourable senator and an honourable member with responsibilities, on behalf of the Opposition, in defence matters, to the effect that the Australian Defence Force has nine careerists for every one soldier and that there is `a proliferation of uniformed politicians in the corridors of Russell Hill'. Is there any substance to these allegations and, if so, what will the Government do about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen some of those comments in the media over the last few days. I have to express some disappointment in them because I believe they are very much redneck comments aimed not at a constructive debate about defence issues but at essentially inflaming the situation. The first accusation to be dealt with was by Mr Taylor, who is the member for Groom and a former serviceman himself. He made the accusation that there is a proliferation of politicians in or out of uniform in the corridors of Russell Hill. That comes as news to me and I must say that, in my dealings with those in the upper echelon of the ADF, I have found that their political views are their own and they are never discussed with me, nor do I wish to know their voting patterns or, indeed, their political preference. It has to be a commitment, I believe, to the best interests of the Australian Defence Force on which appointments in the Australian Defence Force are based. It should never be politicised and the accusation by Mr Taylor I regard as fairly outrageous and I am sure it is regarded by those people who serve this country well as a fairly substantial insult.

ANSWER.PARA: I was also very disappointed with my colleague Senator MacGibbon over a couple of comments he made. These seem to be somewhat out of character with some of the other thoughtful pieces I have seen recently that have been written by him. Senator MacGibbon, interviewed on radio and getting very excited I might add, said:

Well I think without being unkind, we've now got 2 streams of people in the defence forces in Australia. I mean people wearing uniform, not in the civilian category. We've got the careerists who are interested in their own personal career and we've got the soldiers-in all 3 services-and unfortunately you've got about 9 careerists for every 1 soldier.

TALK.START.PARA: —It happens to be true, Minister.

—Well, the senator has reaffirmed his slander here today, and I am here to deny it on behalf of those people who cannot defend themselves. From my experience from visiting 60 per cent of the military bases-and I would have done the whole lot had it not been for the Gulf conflict-that is not my impression of members of the Australian Defence Force. To say that they are some sort of grubby careerists, do not worry about the Australian Defence Force or are not worried about their profession is an absolute slander on the servicemen in Australia. The military ethos that has been created in this country is group well-being and not the individual.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator MacGibbon went on to make another statement that I might not have replied to had it not come from a politician. He said:
Oh yes, we've got a great surplus of people with comfortable waistlines-
I know that certainly applies to me-

sitting behind desks in air conditioned offices in Canberra looking for the next first class air ticket around the world to go to some conference in London or Washington-nowhere stressful of course-and we just don't have enough people where it counts at the fighting end of the machine and that's got to be cleaned up.

I think there is some relevant argument about the ratio of personnel in support and those at the sharp end, the combat end. But for a politician and the travellers opposite to label the majority of officers as just hanging around waiting for the next first class air ticket is hypocrisy. I am trying to find a non-tripper in this chamber. Is there one? Yes, Senator Kernot. Senator Bourne should not put her hand up; she is going to Tibet. Poor old Senator Herron has missed out in the party room. The rest are as guilty as anyone else of liking some travel. But it is for what purpose? Most people in this chamber travel for a good purpose-to broaden their education, to see how systems work overseas and to bring back those advantages. I am one who encourages senior officers of the Defence Force to visit their counterparts in this region and to develop a degree of military transparency so that trust will follow.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a marvellous interview.

—The truth is that Senator MacGibbon-he is now trying to defend himself-does not really believe most of this. He got a bit excited on talkback radio and decided to slander everyone in the Defence Force.
—He is certainly not a careerist.

—As Senator Collins points out, we cannot accuse Senator MacGibbon of being a careerist. He was on the front bench for about three months before he went back to where he is at the moment. I am not trying to belittle every one of Senator MacGibbon's views because I do acknowledge that some of the articles he has written on defence are of a high quality. But it is these sorts of non-thinking verbal outbursts that are very damaging to the morale of the military. I would not have raised the matter here but for the fact that we have had two prime examples of this in the last week.

ANSWER.PARA: There are serious issues to be debated in the defence arena, and they should be debated. But I hope that they are debated on a basis which will not denigrate Australian servicemen, many of whom are dedicated and many of whom have given up better career opportunities to stay in the defence forces. For them to be called careerists, trippers and politicians does absolutely nothing to enhance morale in the Australian Defence Force.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FUNDING OF HOSPITALS IN WESTERN AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. The Minister's Western Australian Labor colleague and State Minister for Health has stated that Federal funding for Western Australian hospitals has declined 22 per cent to the lowest per capita level in Australia. Why is this so and what criteria did the Minister use in assessing that reduced funding allocation?
—I will take that question on notice and I will seek a reply from the Minister for Community Services and Health.

—Will the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs comment on the interest rate policies of Australian banks with regard to their credit card customers in light of the decline in general and mortgage rates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly believe that banks should ensure their credit card users get the benefit of the lowering of interest rates. I believe as money is cheaper to them they should pass on the benefit of that low interest rate money to their customers, but not simply to home buyers. As far as I am concerned, good luck to those who have had the advantage of reductions in their mortgage repayments, but many hundreds of thousands of Australians who use credit cards have not had the benefit of a reduction in interest rates and I am quite sure that they are entitled to that reduction. Despite protestations to the contrary from the bankers' spokesmen, the fact is that the Commonwealth Bank of Australia has managed to signal its intention to reduce its Bankcard rate by, I think, 1.6 per cent in early July. So there is room for a downward movement in interest rates on credit cards and I believe the other banks ought to pass on the benefit of those reduced rates to their various customers. I certainly challenge them to do the same.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Bankers Association has claimed that this is an unprofitable part of a bank's operations. It says that about one-third of the users of credit cards do not pay interest because they have the hide, apparently, to repay the amount that is indicated on their account within the timeframe set. But the Bankers Association spokespeople never mention that the retailers, restaurateurs, motel owners and hotel operators all pay a merchant fee to the banks and that the banks certainly get revenue from all those transactions from the merchants who use this credit card facility. That is never mentioned by the banks concerned.

I believe there is room for the banks to pass on the benefit of lower interest rates. If they do not, certainly consumers and customers should use their power in the market place to shop around and treat the credit cards in the same way as they do when they make a purchase at Woolworths Ltd, K Mart, David Jones (Aust) Pty Ltd, or Myer Stores Ltd, and get the benefit of a bank or financial institution which provides credit card facilities at the lower end of the scale of interest rates. In other words, they should use their power in the market place in regard to this financial product as they do when they shop for other products.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I may be wrong about this, but to the best of my knowledge I have never had a greenie in the hand. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I refer to the same article, in which Senator Collins is quoted extensively and conveniently. The article stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Bob Collins put it a bit differently when asked much the same question by hordes of reporters yesterday. ``It was a very bad decision for the Northern Territory,'' he said, ``but I have to concede that it's probably the correct political decision for the Government to take nationally.'' Nobody could mistake what Collins was saying.
Does Senator Collins still say that he is going to have to take a very difficult decision in Cabinet this week, and what side will Senator Collins be coming down on in this debate?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tambling is getting weaker and weaker, I am afraid. I certainly was responsible for making the second statement; I recognise that. But I certainly did not make the first statement.
—It was very honest.

—Yes, indeed. I thought it was. I tend to be a bit like that, despite 15 years in this business. As I said again, the Cabinet, to the best of my knowledge, will be debating this important issue, on which there are many and divided views. I might add that, from recent public opinion polling, if we can place any weight on that-and as a result of the New South Wales election, I think we have to be a little circumspect about doing that-we can see that opinions in the community at large are well divided on this issue, as well as opinions within the ranks of the Government and, indeed, I am sure, the ranks of the Opposition. The Cabinet will be debating this issue, I think on Thursday, and I will be there.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. It concerns air safety in Australia. I refer the Minister to the agreed upon restructuring process within the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA), which identified staff cuts of 27 per cent to airworthiness surveyors as the minimum level agreed to by all parties to maintain adequate airworthiness checks. Is it true that, under the new management, the number of airworthiness surveyors is about to be reduced by a further cut of up to 55 per cent? Can the Minister confirm that there will be enough airworthiness officers and resources to carry out full safety surveillance of aircraft, especially when we consider that lack of airworthiness accounts for 28 per cent of all plane crashes and when both the number of planes in use and the number of air fatalities in general aviation are on the increase in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can certainly confirm without equivocation that the primary role of the CAA is and will remain air safety. I think it does a fairly impressive job of carrying that out. What I will not do, however, is pre-empt the evaluation that the CAA has been undertaking of its staff resources. That evaluation will be concluded by the end of this month and, I think quite properly, the first people that the CAA should communicate that information to, along with me, are the staff of the CAA.

ANSWER.PARA: An opposition senator-You have been told.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not correct. There is a very significant amount of negotiation and discussion to go on with in the CAA in the overhaul of its services. There is no question at all that there will be some pain experienced, as there always is when change is made in an organisation.

ANSWER.PARA: Significant changes are being contemplated in the CAA which have significant ramifications for staff with no diminution at all to the safety aspects. The CAA is moving, with my full support, to a position where the management of Australian air space will be overhauled and brought more closely into line with international practice and where the air traffic control systems that we operate in this country will be brought up to date by utilising the technology that is now available and by reducing the number of centres that provide air traffic control.

In Australia, we are still in the absurd position of having air traffic control sectors which are modelled on State boundaries, for no good reason other than that they are modelled on State boundaries. If the air traffic control system goes ahead as it is currently proposed-indeed, I think it will be amended; it will not go ahead as currently proposed-over a period of five years, it will not only produce an air traffic control system which is safer but also require something in excess of 1,000 fewer people to operate. Clearly, that will have ramifications for the staff of the CAA.

The internal review is almost complete. It will be finished by the end of this month. I assure the Senate that the primary responsibility of the CAA is, and under this Government will always remain, that of safety.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister's answer concentrated on in-the-air safety factors whereas I specifically asked about airworthiness engineers. Can the Minister confirm that this change will not occur but that if it does it will not lead to related changes? What factors have changed to make this minimum level which has been agreed upon no longer relevant?

—The reason that I did not specifically single out airworthiness surveyors is that the resources review, of which I am sure Senator Kernot is well aware, involves the entire human resources of the CAA-not just air worthiness surveyors, but everybody. That review is almost complete. Its findings will be published in a public document very shortly after they have been communicated to the staff of the CAA. That will occur by the end of this month. I have no intention of pre-empting that here in the Senate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support to the coroner's report on the crash of a Mitsubishi MU2 at Meekatharra in Western Australia on 26 January 1990 in which the coroner was critical of the Civil Aviation Authority's system of inspection for imported aircraft. The coroner said:

QUESTION.PARA: It is clear that the system to some extent is failing and allowing aircraft to fly in Australia which are not airworthy.
What measures has the Minister put in place or does he intend to put in place to prevent any such aircraft again `getting through the net'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Aircraft never did. I have not yet had an opportunity of reading the coroner's report, although I am well aware of what the report said. I do intend to read the coroner's findings in full when I get the opportunity to do so. The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation has probably established some world class initiatives in the investigation of the unfortunate accidents involving this particular type of aircraft. The investigations that have been completed to this point in time related to the tendency of this type of aircraft to be subject to icing at particular altitudes.

ANSWER.PARA: In fact, for some significant time the aircraft have been restricted in Australia to freight operations only, without being able to carry passengers. At this stage it is fair to say that one of the reasons why this type of aircraft is so prevalent in this country is that they were regarded as high performance aircraft and they were on sale in Australia at prices that were extremely cheap, which made them attractive to companies to buy.

The fact is that the safety authorities in Australia not only reacted promptly and properly in the investigation of these accidents, but also the research that was carried out by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) probably created a world first in the investigation of this particular kind of accident.

On one of the very early visits that I made to the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation I listened to some of the voice tapes from the cockpit voice recorders that the Bureau holds-and some of them are extremely difficult to listen to. One of them contained the voice cockpit recording of an ex-BASI employee who was himself at the controls of one of these aircraft and recorded his last messages as the aircraft was going in, relaying information over the cockpit voice recorder that he clearly thought would be of use to the accident investigators, which it subsequently was.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was this one.

—Indeed. All I can say is that I will read the coroner's report but at this stage, on all the information available to me, the safety authorities that I am responsible for behaved very properly in their investigations of the accidents involving these aircraft.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. What is the Government's latest advice from the Human Rights Commissioner, Mr Burdekin, concerning the Government's proposed ban on political advertising?

I have decided today to make available Mr Burdekin's letter and also the advice from the Office of International Law of the Attorney-General's Department. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented in the response by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) to a dorothy dixer about an Australian Broadcasting Corporation interview of mine, which obviously caused the Government some irritation and discomfort. I have never denigrated any Australian service man or woman at any time. If Government senators care to seek evidence to the contrary, I would be very interested because the Senate record will show that I have never denigrated any Australian service man or woman.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point is that at no time have I criticised the politicisation or referred to the politics of any member of the Department of Defence. It is implicit in Senator Robert Ray's answer that I was probably guilty by association with this theme. The third point is that I never referred to anyone as a grubby careerist. That was a phrase used by the Minister in his response to that dorothy dixer.
