TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death, on 21 May 1991, of Mr Rajiv Gandhi, a former Prime Minister of India.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) records its deep regret at the death, on 21 May 1991, of Rajiv Gandhi, former Prime Minister of India;
(b) expresses its deep sympathy to Mrs Sonia Gandhi and family, and to the people of India, in their bereavement;
(c) urges all Indians to respond to this outrage by strengthening their commitment to democracy; and
(d) requests that this motion be conveyed by the President on behalf of the Australian Parliament to the Government of India.''

Mr President, the assassination of Rajiv Gandhi was a despicable and senseless act of violence. It was a tragedy for India and for its people. It must not become also a tragedy for India's political process. I hope that all Australians, including every member of this chamber, will join me in expressing our profound sorrow and regret at his untimely death.

Mr Gandhi assumed the reins of power and the responsibilities of national leadership at a relatively young age and under very difficult circumstances. He accepted the challenge with courage, commitment and a sense of duty that was truly admirable. As Prime Minister, Mr Gandhi set about reforming, modernising and consolidating development in his country of some 800 million people. He was an innovator, introducing many policies designed to equip India to meet the challenges of the twenty-first century.

His insights and cooperation on international issues, particularly on such difficult questions as South Africa, were of enduring value. Everyone who met him in the Commonwealth found him tenacious and constructive as well as a man of considerable personal charm. In regional and international affairs, Mr Gandhi sought a responsible and measured role for India. He attempted to forge closer relations with Pakistan, and he was the first Indian leader to visit China since the 1950s.

Australia's long-standing friendship with India was strengthened considerably during Rajiv Gandhi's prime ministership. He was personally committed to maintaining a strong relationship with us. As recently as last month, Rajiv Gandhi spoke with a member of this Parliament, Senator Graham Maguire, of his desire for closer ties between our two countries. It is true that our economic ties have never been as close as they should be or could be. That is all the more reason why we should mourn the loss of one such as Rajiv Gandhi, committed as he was to strengthening those ties. Honourable senators will recall Prime Minister Gandhi's visit to Australia in 1988 when there was a series of discussions about the strengthening of economic ties between the two countries, which were followed up in subsequent discussions and exchanges between governments, industry and other personnel.

Mr President, Rajiv Gandhi's contribution to India's democracy and parliamentary government followed the strong tradition set by his grandfather, Jawaharlal Nehru who was a founder of independent India and its first Prime Minister, and his mother, Indira Gandhi. During the visit of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to India in 1989, he delivered the Third Indira Gandhi Memorial Lecture. That evening was chaired by Rajiv Gandhi. In his concluding comments on that occasion, he spoke movingly of his mother and of her admiration for Australia, and described the new recognition, the new understanding and the sense of common purpose which make India and Australia partners in the great tasks ahead. He said that he looked forward to building, in partnership with Australians, a new era in Indo-Australian relations. For any democracy to lose two leaders of the stature of Indira Gandhi and Rajiv Gandhi is to suffer a doubly grievous blow. However, we have confidence that India is resilient enough to overcome this loss and to endure this provocation.

On a personal note-I am sure other colleagues, particularly my colleague Senator Evans, will have more to say about this-on the occasions of my two meetings with Rajiv Gandhi, the last time in India, I can add nothing to the widespread opinion of his personal charm and engaging nature, except that, to me, he was a person of lively intellectual curiosity with a great enthusiasm for ideas. That is exciting to see in anyone in politics, particularly when one looks around here. That was a very attractive quality in the former Prime Minister.

We have all been robbed of the greater contribution that this man, still relatively young, could have made to his nation and to the world. His widow and family have been robbed of the presence of a husband and father. It is to that tragic family, and to the nation it has served so well, that our thoughts are directed with this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I support the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and express our deepest sympathy to the family of the late Rajiv Gandhi, former Prime Minister of India, and to the people of India generally. Rajiv Gandhi's tragic assassination, at the age of 46, deprived India of a political leader committed to democratic government and the well-being of his nation, a leader who still had much of his national and international career before him. The violence of his death is abhorrent and an anathema to peace-loving peoples worldwide.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, tragedy of this nature has dogged the Indian nation and was a potential danger-a danger of which Mr Gandhi was well aware-throughout his political career. The assassination of Indira Gandhi, which led to Rajiv Gandhi's election as Prime Minister in 1984, was not the first such example. It is to be hoped that Mr Gandhi's death does not signal the start of another spiral of violence between the diverse groups in India. Indeed, we commend the people of India for their courage and determination to avoid any such additional tragedy in this time of national grief.

Rajiv Gandhi came from a family with a long and proud heritage. He assumed leadership of the Congress (I) Party, and of India, with an unwavering commitment to his country, characteristic of his grandfather, Nehru, and his mother. From having little direct participation in politics prior to his mother's assassination, Rajiv Gandhi became a respected politician of national and international stature.

Rajiv Gandhi achieved much during his time as leader of the Congress (I) Party and of India. One aspect of this achievement which I would particularly like to note was his contribution to constructive internationalism which saw India playing a greater role in world affairs. I mention particularly his leadership role in the non-aligned movement-NAM-which was assumed under his leadership of India, and also the prominent role India continued to play in the Commonwealth under his leadership. That led him to a number of issues, one of which was South Africa, as mentioned by Senator Button, in relation to the contribution of his country in the Commonwealth. Also, he contributed to such difficult issues as the North-South divide to try to overcome these international divisions. At home, Mr Gandhi implemented a program of economic reform-perhaps not as well known-whilst he was Prime Minister, attempting to reduce dependence on nationalised industry and implement greater free market economic policies.

Rajiv Gandhi's assassination, in the middle of national elections, can only be a setback to hopes for the stabilisation of India and the implementation of economic reforms. Mr Gandhi was widely seen as having had the necessary national stature to deal with these problems should he have been given the people's mandate. The determination of the Indian people to remain committed to a stable and democratic environment has been tried many times over the years without really faltering. I am confident that this strength of resolve shown in the quest for peaceful government will once again help India face its current crisis and successfully withstand these challenges to stability and democracy.

Rajiv Gandhi was a committed political leader whose untimely and violent death is a great loss for India and for the Commonwealth. On behalf of the Opposition, I extend to his widow and children our sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to associate the Australian Democrats with the motion of condolence on the death of Mr Rajiv Gandhi. Like most Australians, I would imagine, I was profoundly shocked to hear the news of Mr Gandhi's murder. In fact, I heard about it on the 7 o'clock news just before leaving for work, and I remember thinking that I just did not believe it. I am sure that that is the case with most Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: In the past India has justifiably prided itself on the creed of non-violence espoused by Mahatma Gandhi, which was one of the key elements in its achieving independence from Britain in 1947. Rajiv Gandhi was three years old when that independence was achieved and his grandfather, Mr Nehru, became India's first Prime Minister. Mr Gandhi's mother, Mrs Indira Gandhi, was murdered while Prime Minister of India in 1984. Mr Gandhi, as we all know, was murdered a few days ago at an election rally.

Rajiv Gandhi's family has suffered profoundly at the hands of that special breed of lunatic who believes that murder may be justified. Murder cannot be justified. No cause gains any sympathy by killing an innocent person. Mahatma Gandhi once said:
Every murder or other injury, no matter for what cause, committed or inflicted on another, is a crime against all humanity.

Rajiv Gandhi's murder is a crime against all of us. On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I extend our deep sympathy to Mrs Sonia Gandhi and her children, and our hopes that they may now be left to live their lives in peace and security.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the National Party of Australia, I join the Senate in expressing deep regret at the untimely death of Rajiv Gandhi, the former Prime Minister of India. Rajiv Gandhi came from a remarkable family in the political history of modern India, which dominated both the Indian political scene and the Congress Party over the past 40 years. The grandson of Nehru, the founding Prime Minister of India, Rajiv Gandhi followed his mother, Indira Gandhi, as Prime Minister of India after her tragic assassination in 1984. Serving as Prime Minister from 1984 to 1989, Rajiv Gandhi became the third generation of his family to hold the position of Prime Minister of India.

SPEECH.PARA: India is the world's second most populous country, consisting of 880 million people, and the world's most populous democracy. Rajiv Gandhi was widely tipped to regain office as Prime Minister in the current elections and India's continuation as a democracy was said to rest with his success. Mr Gandhi played a major role on the world stage. He was head of the non-aligned movement, maintaining that non-alignment was the assertion of our right to look at the world in the way that we see it.

He also maintained warm ties with the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics but at the same time broadened India's ties with the United States of America. Under Rajiv Gandhi, India and Australia shared many ideals on international and regional issues. We were members of the Commonwealth together, often promoting identical views at the Commonwealth heads of government meetings. Mr Gandhi visited Australia in 1986 and was instrumental in fostering an appreciation of our mutual interests. Mr Gandhi actively promoted continuing improvements in our relationship. At the time, he expressed a great desire to bring our two countries together in closer friendship, recognising our close regional proximity and opportunities for trade and cooperation.

On behalf of the National Party I join with my colleagues in the Senate in expressing regret at the death of Rajiv Gandhi at such an early age. Mr President, the passing of Rajiv Gandhi is a tragic loss to India, and his contribution to international affairs will be sadly missed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —As all honourable senators will be aware, I had the honour of representing Australia, along with Mrs Hazel Hawke, the wife of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), at the funeral of Rajiv Gandhi in Delhi last Friday. I take this opportunity to add just a few words of my own to what has already been so well said by the party leaders.

SPEECH.PARA: Funerals are always moving and harrowing occasions, particularly so when conducted in accordance with the Indian cremation rites which are an immensely visual and tactile way of farewelling departed souls. A funeral is always harrowing when a person is struck down in the prime of life. It is always harrowing when the person involved is someone who has done a great deal for his or her country; the pain of the loss is that much more obvious when that is so. A funeral is harrowing, too, when it is of a person who has done a great deal for the international community and who is being lost forever from that stage.

But a funeral is particularly harrowing, particularly gruelling, when one has some personal knowledge of the person in question. While I cannot claim the degree of personal friendship that our Prime Minister unquestionably had with Rajiv Gandhi and his family as a whole, I did have the benefit of three or four very long conversations with him over the last two or three years and a number of other more fleeting contacts. On the basis of that acquaintanceship, I do have to say that Rajiv Gandhi was really one of the most charming, delightful people that I have come across in public life.

He was a person who was immensely interested and engaged in whatever the subject matter of the conversation was, as Senator Button has said so well. He was someone who, incidentally, was almost exactly my own age-I think there was a difference of just a couple of weeks-and on the basis of that and other things we established a degree of rapport which I certainly have felt with very few other international leaders whom I have had the privilege to meet.

The man really did have none of those characteristics, or perhaps character defects, that we tend to associate with professional politicians. We all know in this chamber what I am talking about. I guess that is a function of the fact that he was not by nature, by instinct, a professional politician. He did not become a politician by choice but rather out of a sense of duty, a sense of obligation and a sense of what his country required.

He was manifestly unhappy about the tag of arrogance or distance that had been associated with him and which had something to do with his previous electoral defeat. That kind of characterisation was foreign to his nature. It was not an accurate depiction of the character of the man, as I hope I have said. Quite apart from the political implications, he wanted to be able to throw off that characterisation of him and to be seen by the Indian people for the man that he was.

Thus he put aside most of the security apparatus that had surrounded him in his previous campaigns and in his previous prime ministerial life. This time he conducted a campaign in a way that made him extraordinarily vulnerable to the kind of tragedy that ultimately occurred. He knew that but he was prepared to take that risk. Quite apart from anything else, he was an extraordinarily brave and courageous man.

Rajiv Gandhi's passing in such appalling circumstances really is a tragedy for India, which has lost a fine leader and a fine man. It is a tragedy for Australia, which has lost a very good friend indeed. It is a tragedy for the larger international community, which has lost a man of real stature. He showed this by his performance, for example, in the context of the Commonwealth negotiations over apartheid in South Africa, in which our own Prime Minister was so intimately involved. It was also shown by the role he played in the non-aligned movement-a role which was wholly constructive, sane, rational and devoted to trying to shape and direct that movement in a way that was responsive to the new currents that were operating in international affairs.

Above all, his passing is a tragedy for his own family. It is something that must have been very hard indeed for Sonia, Priyanka and Rahul to bear. They conducted themselves with extraordinary dignity and courage in the very gruelling circumstance that they were put through in the funeral last Friday. I convey to them again publicly here the very deeply felt condolences that I was privileged to be able to convey last Friday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I follow the remarks made by my colleagues on both sides of this chamber in expressing my own deep regret at this appalling loss with the tragic death of Rajiv Gandhi. Just today I returned from a short visit to Canada and the United States of America. Last Tuesday I happened to be in the Canadian Parliament when this terrible news came. Shock and disbelief was expressed by those in my immediate company as well as by those in the Canadian Parliament that day. Throughout the world there is this reaction of great sadness at this appalling loss for India and for the world.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the remarks of those honourable senators who have already spoken by referring to three particular events that I will always hold dear when I think of Rajiv Gandhi. The first is particular to Australia. Rajiv Gandhi visited here in 1986 and, as Prime Minister, spoke at a reception and in other ways visited with some of us in this Parliament. This was in many ways the start of the renewal of Australia-India relations in these last five or six years. There were complementary visits by our own Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and other members of this Parliament to India. There was genuine bipartisan support, and there still is, for the upward growth and renewal of our economic and other relations which really began with Rajiv Gandhi's visit to this country.

As one who visited India for a few months when I was an undergraduate in 1966, and as one who has studied some aspects of the social and political developments of India, I was reminded by his visit that our relationship had lapsed and that it needed to be given content, meaning, energy and effort again on both sides. We have seen that effort and energy in reasonable measure.

Secondly, I wish to refer to the economic reform that Rajiv Gandhi brought to his own country. From the beginning of his time when, so unhappily, he succeeded his assassinated mother in the position of Prime Minister, profound reassessments of the Indian economy were under way. This led to a clear call by those commissioned to give advice-including Professor Jha, Dr Abid Hussein who has now become my friend, and others-to open up the Indian economy and see it approach more international competitiveness with less protection and all the reforms that come from direct competition. Rajiv Gandhi had his heart in this, and I believe that the success of the Indian economy in the past five or six years has flowed from these kinds of reforms. I salute him and I salute those who advised him in setting out on that path, and I wish it to be continued.

The third and final matter that I wish to refer to is Rajiv Gandhi's own deep sense of the need for reform within his own party, the Congress Party. I have at other times referred to his inspiring speech at the centenary function of the Congress Party in Bombay on 28 December 1985. I seek leave to incorporate a summary of Rajiv Gandhi's speech on that occasion.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

In his inaugural address to the Congress Centenary Session in Bombay on 28 December 1985, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi surveyed the history of the party and recalled its struggle for independence and for making India a modern self-reliant nation.

However, towards the end of the address he frankly criticised the administration, industry, trade unions, the education system, justice, the Congress Party and the Opposition. The following are his observations:
Institutions: Too often, behind their imposing facades, the spirit and substance lack vitality.
Justice: The poor have little hope of timely redress.
Industry: We have industrialists untouched by the thrusting spirit of great risk-takers and innovators.
Trade Unions: They now protect the few who have, oblivious of millions who have not. They feel little concern for the creation of national wealth, only for a larger and larger share.
Universities: Teachers seldom teach and students seldom learn. Strike, mass copying, agitations are more attractive alternatives.

Government Servants: We have government servants who do not serve but oppress the poor and the helpless, police, who do not uphold the law but shield the guilty, tax collectors who do not collect taxes but connive with those who cheat the State.
Congress Party: Good Congress workers are handicapped, for on their backs ride the brokers of power and influence, who dispense patronage to convert a mass movement into a feudal oligarchy.
Corruption is not only tolerated but even regarded as the hallmark of leaderships.
Opposition: Non-congress parties have shown a cynical disregard for sensitive issues of national security.
Mr Gandhi called for less consumption and more production and told the partymen to re-establish contacts with the masses.

TALK.START.PARA: —As is clear from this summary, and indeed from the speech itself, there is no complacency about his own party's achievements after 100 years. He was directly factual and, I believe, truthful and just in his direct criticisms of his own party and the call he made for much higher goals and a much higher performance from his own colleagues. To some extent, his defeat as Prime Minister in the 1987 election resulted from his not being able to gain his party's support for the program that he outlined in the goals that he set forward in 1985 in the early stage of his leadership of the Congress Party.

SPEECH.PARA: In looking at him, I do not see complacency or arrogance, nor do I see him only as the grandson of Jawaharlal Nehru or the son of Indira Gandhi. I see him as a person who was thrust into high office in India; who served his country well; who re-examined the status of his party and country; who set out a reform program for Congress and for the Indian economy; and who even sought to renew and build afresh his relationship with Australia. I salute him for all these points and for his essential humanity. I pass my condolences to his wife Sonia, his children and to all those who were close to him. As is stated in the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), I add my own hope that, as a response to this tragic event, there will be a higher commitment in India to democracy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I also support this condolence motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) this afternoon. The world saw an appalling loss last week, and certainly India has shared in that appalling loss. A very good man who was a leader, but a reluctant leader, was cut down in the prime of his life. He was a very vigorous person who was ready to take up the challenge to lead India if called upon by the President after the election. This has not been just India's loss; it is more than that. Obviously it is a loss for the region and certainly a loss for the world. Also, it is a significant loss for us in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Gandhi was very much a friend of Australia. He visited Australia in 1986 and was the only Indian Prime Minister to have done so. He had a very positive attitude to Australia and clearly was a very great admirer of our present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). When I met with Mr Gandhi in India, he said that he wanted to further improve relations with Australia and, as he stated, to put them on a fast track so that the potential in our relationship could in fact be given effect to in the future. He spoke of improved regional cooperation with Australia and, significantly, the focus of that was about keeping the peace. That was the focus that Mr Gandhi had as recently as last month when he said that India and Australia should work together in the region and elsewhere in the world to bring about peace. Certainly, in that context, he was talking about the current situation in Cambodia.

In his period as Prime Minister and following that period, Mr Gandhi certainly pursued the agenda of opening India to the world. That included not only foreign policy but particularly the Indian economy. He was very keen to liberalise, open up and deregulate the Indian economy, and I am sure that few in India would disagree with that particular sentiment.

It was only last month that Mr Gandhi welcomed me into his home in New Delhi. In fact, our meeting took place beneath a magnificent oil painting of his mother, Indira Gandhi, who was cut down by assassins in 1984. This home of the Gandhi family has been violated by this senseless act. I remember Mr Gandhi at the time as being very relaxed, thoughtful and certainly very well-briefed on what he was planning to do with regard to economic reform in India if elected. What struck me particularly and what was most noticeable about Mr Gandhi was that he was a leader and a politician who was really interested in a genuine exchange of ideas. He wanted to hear my views as an Australian as well as to put his views forward. It was very clear to me that Mr Gandhi was a very unusual figure for a world leader in that he was both a listener as well as a talker.

He of course followed his mother into the position of Prime Minister of India after a very violent act in 1984. I think those people who would perpetrate violence must be made to realise that violence is senseless, short-sighted and achieves nothing. The perpetrators, if they gain anything from acts of violence gain it only in the short term; they certainly achieve nothing over the longer haul. Acts of violence are a plunge into the dark abyss where the rules of decent civilised human behaviour are broken. Everybody loses and nobody gains from acts of violence.

Last week a very dark act was perpetrated in the bright light of Tamil Nadu. It fouled the very democratic process in India. It occurred just as the Indian people were exercising their right to choose a leader for their country-a right that many people are fighting for in other parts of the world. This afternoon I would like to add my sentiments to those already expressed here. I express my deepest sympathy to Mrs Sonia Gandhi and her family, the President of India, and the people of India.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the condolence motion on behalf of the Greens Western Australia who also express grief at the brutal assassination of Rajiv Gandhi and those who died with him. These other people who died were truly the innocent victims of mindless violence. Of course, it is a personal loss to the Gandhi family and a personal loss, in a very real sense, to millions of Indians but it is also a great political loss to that country, particularly because it is such a great challenge to the democratic process in India.

SPEECH.PARA: I mention very briefly the international contribution that Rajiv Gandhi made several years ago when, as Prime Minister, he was one of six heads of government who lobbied the nuclear superpowers in favour of nuclear disarmament. He did that through the sponsorship of the group Parliamentarians for Global Action. It was a very successful working group-not that we have achieved nuclear disarmament, but certainly the efforts of Rajiv Gandhi and other leaders who worked with him were quite substantial in furthering that international debate.

Of course it is true to say that violence begets violence and that it does not solve anything. It never has and it never will. I think this has been dramatically demonstrated yet again in India-as if we needed that proved again in the world community. India has been plunged into chaos by this act of violence and I would like to support what Senator Bourne and Senator Maguire have said on that subject. It is not something in which anybody can take consolation, I think, even in the short term.

India, where non-violence had one of its greatest adherents in the form of Mahatma Gandhi, has been plunged into violence again and that is a tragic loss for all of us, as well as for the Indian people. I would like to express sympathy to the family of Rajiv Gandhi and also to the families of those who died with him.

The speech read as follows-

Banking is, of course, one of the most fundamental and integral processes of modern society. It touches the daily lives of us all. Clearly, in a healthy democracy, those who hold the power and privilege of being bankers and who administer these processes on our behalf have the most profound of responsibilities to society. Yet there is ample evidence that banking is not being practised at its best in Australia today. Every daily newspaper in recent months has catalogued the dimensions of dissatisfaction with this most vital of financial and social processes. Recent history provides us with some remarkable examples of institutional financing at its worst- one needs only cite the revelations of the Nugan/Hand Royal Commission; the exposes in relations to Rothwells in Western Australia, Tricontinental, Pyramid and Farrow in Victoria to evidence the travesty of what has passed for banking in this country in recent years. Furthermore, the crash of a number of high profile Australian entrepreneurs who had been generously and imprudently bankrolled by Australia's leading bankers has very severely damaged an already suspect Australian image overseas.

Whilst concurrent royal commissions into state banking and the Federal Parliamentary Inquiry will go some way into examining specific aspects of bank practise, in the eyes of many they will not go far enough. In my view and that of many key witnesses, the current Bank Inquiry will not come to grips with the more serious aspects of banking malpractices in Australia. The premature and extraordinary disregard of vital evidence placed before it, and apparent lack of fortitude of the Inquiry, highlights a glaring need for a royal commission in order to de-politicise the investigative process thereby allowing a true revelation of the excesses and abuses of Australian banking in the 90's.

The Australian Democrats have consistently argued that the deregulation of banking in the early 80's dramatically shifted the orientation of banking towards profit and that this shift, together with inadequate supervision of the banking system, has transformed the ethos of banking to the detriment of many aspects of Australian life, especially small business and farming.

There is no escaping the fact that banks enjoy a most extraordinary privilege-viz. the power to create credit estimated by conservative bankers at seven times held deposits, some would be far more audacious. If you and I were able to multiply our bank balance sevenfold and to continue to do so to any further deposits that might come our way, we would be delighted. This privilege, of course, becomes even more potent when banks lend these extraordinary windfalls to the less fortunate at exorbitant rates of interest.

These realities are powerful enough in themselves but they became far more so when banking became profit driven in a deregulated market. This has, of course, been the situation in Australia in the 80's and 90's. As Australia's major banks have successfully pursued `superprofits', (a devastatingly appropriate term coined by Mr. Don Argus, Managing Director of National Australia Bank, in a confidential memo), ordinary Australians have paid an enormous price. Some argue that the provision of credits by banks is the essential dynamism of the economy in the prevailing development oriented model of today. However, credit is debt and the massive indebtedness of today-including personal, foreign and commercial debt-has been substantially and deliberately created and exploited by banks in their successful pursuit of superprofits.

The difficulties which have flowed from massive indebtedness accompanying the bonanza of credit creation are frightening in their dimensions. When banks create credit they do so by mere ink on paper, or more accurately these days, with the flick of computer keys. However, they require that the borrower secure these debts with real assets such as a farm, a business or a home, (this is the crucial step which is the essence of the banks' power). They then require that borrowers service these debts at extraordinary levels of interest-rates of 18-34% have been quite common in the past few years. Obviously in servicing such high interest rates, businesses are bled white and are left unable to promote, develop, research or market products. These, of course, are the very processes which make for vibrant small business and primary producing sectors. Furthermore, if borrowers are unable to service these exorbitant rates of interest then the banks foreclose and sell the assets at a fraction of what they valued them in enticing borrowers into the debt in the first place. They can sell at such ridiculous prices because in real terms the bank paid nothing for the asset in the first instance when it acquired it as security by advancing `created' credit.

But in Australia in recent years we have witnessed far beyond even this. In their pursuit of `market share' in the post deregulated context a wide variety of practices have emerged which are now evoking the community's ire. These range from excessive interest and a myriad of charges to malpractice and even corrupt practices. I have tabled much sworn and substantiated evidence in the Senate in the past three years, only some of which, such as the infamous Westpac letters, has received public attention. Certainly the foreign currency loans fiasco demonstrated how innocent borrowers could be gravely damaged by bank greed and suspect practices.

The Westpac letters alone reveal a set of circumstances which warrant a royal commission-Australia's largest law firm, Allen Allen and Hemsley advising Australia's largest commercial bank, Westpac, that it had breached its fiduciary obligations at law, its statutory obligations to the Reserve Bank, had evaded taxes and committed fraud, all to make massive profit at ordinary Australians' expense. The fact that the Treasurer, Attorney General, the current Bank Inquiry, the Leader of the Opposition, and the parliament at large lack the will to address the very real imperatives presented by this evidence is indicative of a deep lack of moral courage. Little wonder, in the light of Nugan/Hand, Rothwells, Tricontinental, foreign currency loans, a timid and impotent Bank Inquiry and the ineffectiveness of the Reserve Bank, that those in the commercial banking sector feel so secure in their power and display such arrogance in its use.

But our concerns should go much beyond that. We now find Australians in thousands moving inexorably towards bankruptcy because they are unable to service indebtedness. There has been in this first quarter of 1991 a 53.6% increase in bankruptcies nationally, with some States experiencing more than 70% increase. The associated foreclosures mean farmers leaving the land and business people leaving their businesses. The four major banks alone have warned shareholders of a massive provision for bad debts of $10 billion.
Those who administer the banking system at the highest level are themselves admitting to mismanagement on a national scale.
The Reserve Bank admits to leniency and bank watchers and finance commentators cite the fact that leading banks have disregarded directives of the Reserve Bank.

Attempts on the part of ordinary Australians to resolve their differences with their banks in the courts have revealed the callousness of banks in exploiting a range of tactics to both obstruct and delay just outcomes and even to pervert the course of justice.

Whole communities such as the Eyre Peninsula and Nyngan have been devastated by bank greed. Many farmers have been reduced to the level of serfs and peasant farmers who will never escape the web of debt unless they are prepared to surrender properties they and their families have owned and farmed for generations. This web of indebtedness is almost all pervasive. The vast majority of real property in this country is to some degree or another mortgaged to financiers, especially to the banking sector. Through rampant foreclosure much Australian property must inevitably change hands. Foreign ownership and social dislocation are the most obvious outcomes, but the human tragedy and disappointment has many less apparent manifestations such as the breakdown of health, marriage and family.

Only a royal commission with both broad and specific terms of reference such as those proposed in this bill will reveal the magnitude and nature of what bank greed has delivered upon Australian society. It is imperative that such a royal commission be initiated at the earliest possible time.

We must cause the words of Ainslie Rothschild, so prophetically and knowingly spoken in 1801, to ring in the ears of all Australians-he said ``allow me to control the credit of the nation and I care not who makes the laws''.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

Mr President

This Bill would repeal Part III of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 and substitute a new Part III which contains the provisions relating to the payment of service pensions and associated benefits for veterans, spouses and other dependants as at 1 July 1990. The most important features of the new Part III include provisions expressed in `plain English', shorter sections than in the current legislation, and easy to follow structure and layout of provisions, with each category of pension dealt with in a separate Division.

The rewrite of Part III does not involve any changes in policy, has no financial impact or effect on Veterans' pensions or entitlements and does not alter in any way the responsibilities of the Repatriation Commission towards the veterans and their dependants. In this sense, the Bill retains existing legislative provisions as at 1 July 1990.

This Bill builds on past achievements in the simplification of Repatriation legislation. The introduction of the 1986 Act to consolidate and rationalise the growing body of Repatriation legislation in a single document was a major step forward in making that legislation more accessible and easier to understand. In the past five years, however, Repatriation legislation has been amended to meet the changing needs of an ageing veteran population and to keep pace with government policy.

This has been particularly so in relation to the income and assets tests applying to service pensions under Part III. The result has been an unavoidable increase in the complexity of these provisions in Repatriation legislation, many of which reflect similar developments in Social Security legislation.

The Social Security Act 1947 has been entirely rewritten in ``plain English'' and was introduced in Parliament on 6 November 1990. Honourable senators will remember that the Social Security Bill 1990 was debated in the second week of the Autumn Sittings.

As with the Social Security Bill 1990, the object of this Bill is to overcome problems associated with understanding legislation by using a `clear English' drafting style and a better format for presenting information. In addition, the introduction of step by step rate calculators consolidates into distinct modules all the provisions relevant to any aspect of the calculation of the rate of pension payable.
With such arrangements in place, claimants for a pension or benefit could also work out their rate of pension.

Another significant feature of the Bill is the repeal of the current section 5 and its replacement by a new section 5, still located in Part I of the 1986 Act, which contains an index to all the definitions used in the Act, while new sections 5A to 5R contain the definitions arranged by subject group. For example, all the war and operational area related definitions are contained under that heading in a new section 5B. These definitions relate to the type and nature of service performed, the areas and the periods of service. These definitions are important in assisting veterans to understand the way these terms are used when determining their entitlement to benefits under the VEA.

The rewrite of Part III has been undertaken in consultation with the ex-service organisations which have been involved from the outset in its planning and organisation. In November last year an exposure draft of the partially completed Bill was provided to these organisations for examination of, and comment on, the content and format of the new Part III. The comments received have been both constructive and helpful in redrafting the legislation.

More recently, extensive consultation has taken place with key representatives of the major ex-service organisations. Comments and suggestions for further improvement arising out of this consultative round have been incorporated into the final Bill.

Amendments to the 1986 Act introduced in the 1990 Budget sittings and any amendments introduced during the current sittings, together with transitional arrangements, will be covered in separate Bills to be introduced later in these sittings. There will be on-going consultation with the exservice organisations in respect of the Rewrite Amendment Bills.

This Bill represents a significant advance in making legislation more accessible to an ageing veteran community. It is in line with the trend towards `plain English' as the preferred form of expression in official documents. It is in line with the `access and equity' policy of this Government. Last but not least, this Bill goes a long way towards meeting the call for simpler legislation by both the ex-service and war widows organisations.
Mr President, considerable effort has been made in completing this Bill to pave the way for more effective administration. I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.

I have since ascertained that she spoke no English. All her jewellery was confiscated, and she was kept for several hours in the custody of Customs. She was hounded in a way which any ordinary person would find quite unacceptable. Subsequently, it was found that all the jewellery, with the exception of one piece, came within the category of personal effects, and that the one piece that had been a gift to her from her workmates upon her leaving to come to another country had pushed her $150 over the $400 limit.

SPEECH.PARA: When I asked the Minister about that case, he said that it was not a question but a huge scenario, and nobody could agree with it. I pointed out that it was a factual case, but the Minister intervened and, finally, Mr Kelly said:
I have no knowledge of the circumstances that you have described that would lead me to identify a particular case . . .
He further stated that:
. . . it would not be our practice to pursue prosecution but, rather, the matter would be dealt with through the administrative penalty regime.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

Where there are allegations of substance, I think it is a great shame that that happens. I certainly will convey that view to Customs. I think it is conscious of this, but it deals with thousands and thousands of issues of this kind, and I believe that the level of complaints of this kind is not high.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish that were so, but the level of complaint is very large and very loud. I remind the Minister that the report of the Law Council of Australia concerning the Australian Customs Service describes it as being Elliot Ness-like. I ask the Minister whether I can be provided with a full breakdown of all costs incurred by the Australian Customs Service, including fees to the Director of Public Prosecutions and any other witnesses' costs that may have been incurred, including aeroplane fares and the like, for the three cases I have listed. I want to know how much it cost the taxpayer to prosecute the Oxford case right up to the door until I raised it in the Senate and it was suddenly settled, how much it cost to prosecute the Lees, how much it has cost to prosecute the Topper case, and the estimated cost of continuing with that case through the courts next month. Can I have that information please?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —That may be very difficult. Customs, after all, is an organisation which is involved in hundreds of investigations and hundreds of prosecutions. To separate these sorts of things out on the basis of three cases will be a very difficult thing to do, I suspect. To attribute particular costs to particular cases would also be a very difficult thing to do. If you are making the point that there are some costs involved in these things, I agree with that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, Customs does have a legal department, as we are fully aware. Anybody who had any knowledge of how a legal practice is run, even within a bureaucracy, would know that there must be proper accounts kept. If there are not, we would have to deal with that separately. That would be deplorable. I would imagine that, if it were even half efficient, those figures should be quite readily available. I would be interested to see them. I mean accurate figures: I do not mean the fudged sort of figures that we were provided with, for instance, for the Midford Paramount case, when we were told that it cost $70,000; I mean the real cost.

SPEECH.PARA: There are just a couple of items that I want to raise quickly relating to page 12 of the reservation on the disclosure of confidential information, where the admission of the disclosure of confidential information was made whereby Customs officers had, in fact, breached the law. I would like to know exactly whether or not further action has been taken by the Australian Customs Service so that information cannot be compromised in this way in the future. What action has been taken, including whether anyone has been charged?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The only information I have is that the information sought by the Estimates Committee was provided on 10 May in writing.

—In dealing with the Lee case, I raised the point that Mr and Mrs Lee had been charged with three charges which arose from the same document. This seems to be in line with the sort of attitude that Customs has with regard to penalties being imposed for each error contained in the same document, and it seems that Customs is relying upon the advice of one Mr Miller. We now have Mr Miller's opinion, on which the decision is based. I asked whether or not that had been checked by senior counsel as to the validity of that, and I now ask the Minister to ask his officers whether or not they concern themselves with the criticism of that type of practice contained in the High Court decision of Scott and Geegan and Sons Pty Ltd, a 1969 case.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot comment on that case. I would have thought the declaration itself, by the terminology of the question, creates an offence in respect of each question which is asked. I do not have a Customs form in front of me but, as I recall, in filling it in one is filled with trepidation in respect of each question and not the questions collectively on the form.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did ask a very specific question. As recorded at page 245 of the Hansard, I asked the following concerning the practice of penalties for each error on a piece of documentation:

SPEECH.PARA: If it has already ceased, I would like to know the date on which it ceased and the reason for cessation of the practice . . . If it has not already ceased, and it is proposed that it soon will cease, I would still like to know the reason that you will cease the practice-which I suspect might be that it is not lawful for you to be doing it in the first place-and then what actions you will be taking to remedy any imposition that anybody has suffered under the previous regime.
The answer which was supplied does not answer those specific questions and, without wasting the time of this Committee further, I simply ask that a better and accurate answer be provided.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry; I suffer from the difficulty of not knowing what Senator Bishop is talking about. I might explain that in this way: she started off by asking me about a 1969 High Court case and in the second part of her question went on to ask me something which I apprehend to be quite different, the first part being about the questions asked in a declaration and whether there was a double or triple jeopardy as a result of the form of the customs declaration. I am afraid that I cannot help with that in the circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: For the record, might I just advise that I have been told in relation to the Oxford case to which Senator Bishop referred that the amount of the penalty was $356. The Customs practice is not to proceed normally where the penalty is less than a threshold of $300. That is what I understand to be the case. In the Topper case, the amount of the penalty was $799. Those figures might be of some help.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. I ask, then: what difference is made by a figure of $150 and not $3, as I asked the Minister before? My advice is that the Topper case is worth $119. Perhaps we can get some clarification as to the discrepancy in the figures.
—Yes.

—To conclude on this matter, with regard to the Minister's discomfiture of not being able to answer the question relating to the practice of making more than one charge where there is more than one error in a single document, I asked him not to give me personally the answer but to ask his officers to accurately answer the question as set out in the Hansard and supplied to his officers. The answer they have given is not answering the question. I simply ask that the Minister redirect the officers to that question. At the same time, I am sure that by now the officers will be familiar with the case I mentioned. I was not expecting the Minister to have been particularly familiar with it, but I am asking that they be familiar with it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want Senator Bishop to worry too much about my discomfort-or discomfiture, as she put it. The point I was making was not that I was unable to answer the question but rather a more personal one-no doubt it is a defect of mine-that I was unable to understand the question let alone answer it. I was not made uncomfortable by that inference. That is another problem. Senator Bishop seeks a further answer to the question she asked at the Estimates Committee. I will see whether officers can supply a further precise answer to that question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —So that we may have it on the record, the relevant part of that High Court case of Taylor J. reads:

SPEECH.PARA: This multiplicity of charges is, to say the least, oppressive and seems to me to be the product of zeal which outruns all sense of proportion. Possibly it may be thought that the greater the number of charges that may be squeezed out of what is substantially one fraudulent transaction the greater the penalty will be. This is not generally so and, indeed, there is no reason why it should be so in the present case.
If the officers are not familiar with that case, I refer them to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will refer them to it; I will have a look at it too. The Committee is certainly not an appeal tribunal from the High Court and I do not want to argue that. I do not know what that case to which Senator Bishop referred was applying to. I am sure it was not applying to the Customs declaration which Mr and Mrs Lee signed; that is one thing we can be sure about. In the winter recess, I will try to dig out that 1969 law report and have a look at it.

—I am sure it will be most gratifying if the Minister's officers could also see it; I think that would be helpful. In the interests of time, and because of the time that has been made available for the Appropriation Bills, I will defer asking any questions at this stage and I will take them up at another time. Perhaps we could move on to the next Department, bearing in mind that we are coming back to the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation and Austrade at 8 o'clock.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the request of senators is that the estimates in respect of my portfolio be adjourned only in respect of Austrade and the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation. That request is before the Senate. In those circumstances, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That further consideration of the motion in respect of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce be postponed till a later hour this day.

TALK.START.PARA: —I confirm with honourable senators that those are the only matters that they wish to have raised, because it might mean that some of the officers who are there now are not required.

—There are many more questions that I would like to ask, but because we are constrained by time, due to the Government's staging of business-being unable to get it on early in the session, and bunching it up in that inefficient way-we will limit the time we will spend on the committee stage of the Appropriation Bill and deal with it in another way.

—I want to make sure, for the benefit of the Minister and his officers, that when we come back to this matter at 8 o'clock the only questions that will be asked will relate to EFIC and Austrade. Is that correct?
—That is right.
—We know that Senator Bishop would have loved to have asked other questions.
—We now move on to the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet.

—I refer to the matter raised in the report of Estimates Committee A which relates to the Resource Assessment Commission survey conducted late last year. The departmental officers who attended the hearing of Estimates Committee A told me that they were completely unaware of the survey. I now note that we have received an answer from those officers to the questions that they were obliged to take on notice. Perhaps Senator McMullan could confirm whether officers are present who are capable of answering questions in relation to that Resource Assessment Commission survey.
—I can confirm that there are officers from the Resource Assessment Commission here.

—My concern is that the report canvassed a whole heap of issues-in particular, questions A6, A7 and A8-which related not to public attitudes on whether we should be logging our forestry reserves but rather to political matters. Could Senator McMullan give an explanation as to why those questions were in the survey?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —From the brief study I have been able to make of it, my understanding is that the history of market research and its analysis around the world indicates, as is obvious, that individuals form their opinions and attitudes from a diverse and large number of sources, which includes political parties and other organisations to which individuals might belong.

SPEECH.PARA: As I am advised, the questions in the survey did not ask how individuals voted in the last election or how they would vote in the next election. The questions sought to determine how the direction and strength of political values relate to other social factors. Political values are, of course, a significant component of social and cultural values and they are part of an analysis of environmental attitudes in Australia.

The inclusion of party identification questions were for the purpose of allowing comparisons with surveys on environmental issues conducted previously in Australia and overseas which use identical or similar wording, including the Eurobarometer series which surveys many current issues in Europe-including environmental issues during the past two decades-and other Australian surveys. These questions may enable future surveys to make comparisons with the rack survey responses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —That answer is not satisfactory, for the very simple reason that Senator McMullan has only canvassed half of the issue. Whether one accepts the assertion that the survey did not ask people their political views, that is certainly not how the constituents with whom I had some lengthy discussions perceived it. They certainly saw the question of whether they thought of themselves as being close to a political party in an election year as being indicative of whether they voted for that political party, but I suppose that is by the bye.

SPEECH.PARA: What really concerns me is questions such as those found in A6. For example, `Income and wealth should be redistributed towards ordinary working people'. Respondents to the survey were asked to indicate whether they believed that statement to be true and to indicate the strength of their identification with that statement. That is totally irrelevant to Senator McMullan's answer that people get their views from political parties. This is asking something which is completely different from their possible support for a political party, and I find that sort of question offensive and objectionable.

This is asking people their views about matters that have absolutely nothing to do with the environment and absolutely nothing to do with forestry. It is great for Senator McMullan to say that questions such as identification with political parties are found in a Eurobarometer survey, but I want to know how questions about wealth redistribution and how unions should be dealt with under the law come anywhere near the ambit of questions in a survey that is supposed to relate to the forestry industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was answering the question Senator O'Chee asked rather than the one he had in mind, but I understand the second point he has now raised concerning A6. I should have thought that anybody who has ever seen and been responsible for the analysis of market research would understand that a fundamental requirement to enable useful analysis of the answers one gets to the primary questions, is the capacity to effectively correlate those answers with other factors to enable subsequent comprehensive statistical analysis to be undertaken.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the first time I have seen this survey. I have not analysed in detail each of the questions and formed a view about whether I think each and every one of them is the most appropriate basis for correlation. There is a range of such questions which is a useful mechanism as an indication of underlying social attitudes and, from that, useful correlations might be drawn.

It is a waste of the taxpayers' money to ask for surveys to be undertaken which ask the basic questions but do not allow questions to be asked which allow effective correlations to be made. There is no doubt that there is justification for the nature of the questions that are in A6. At this stage I cannot leap to the defence of every individual sub-part of it because I have not had the opportunity to study it, but I support the general thrust of doing surveys in that manner. I think it is the only way that anybody conducting such a survey would get value for money from the exercise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that Senator McMullan has indicated that he supports in principle the questions in A6, and that they might provide interesting and useful correlations of views because I am very concerned that the responses to those questions were not contained in the report which subsequently arose as a result of the survey.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McMullan says that those questions are there to allow interesting and useful correlations yet members of parliament, the general public and other interested groups do not have access to the results of questions A6, A7 and A8. As a consequence, the assertion that they make interesting and useful correlations is simply ludicrous because none of us can draw the correlations. Why were the results of those questions not included in the report that arose out of the survey? Who has had the opportunity to make these interesting and important correlations?

TALK.START.PARA: —What has been released until now, I am advised, is simply the consultant's report. The Government has not told the consultant which questions he or she should regard as significant for the purpose of the report. The views of the Resource Assessment Commission on the survey will be published soon when the full report becomes available, and I am advised that the raw data will be available for researchers and others wishing to make use of it for correlation, et cetera, at the conclusion of the inquiry. It is not a secret document. What has been published at the moment is the consultant's report as Senator O'Chee would understand, drawing from it that which a consultant considers to be the highlights and significant correlations. The Commission will draw its conclusions and make its comments subsequently and, at the conclusion of the report, the inform- ation will be available.

—I am interested to note that the consultant did not find questions A6, A7 and A8 interesting and significant because they obviously were not in the consultant's report. Senator McMullan indicated that the raw statistical data will be available. The question I put to Senator McMullan is: exactly when will that raw statistical data become available?
—At the conclusion of the inquiry.
—When is that?
—Currently sche- duled for the end of November.

—I have some concern about this because it is pushing it a long way back. In the interim this information is currently available to the Resource Assessment Commission and, through the Resource Assessment Commission, to the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet. Effectively what this survey has done, especially with a long time lag between when the survey was first conducted and when the raw statistical data will be made available not only to members of the public but also to members of the Opposition, is that this survey has acted as a means by which the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet and our Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, have received opinion polling relating to political issues at taxpayers' expense, which information has been withheld from the Opposition. Therefore, I request Senator McMullan to give an undertaking to provide that raw statistical data forthwith to the Parliament and to table it in the Senate.

—If Senator O'Chee's assumptions were right, his conclusion might be right. I am advised that the material has not been made available, and will not be made available, to the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or anybody else. At this stage it is only the property of the consultant and the Resource Assessment Commission and until it has finished dealing with it, it will not be made available. There does not appear to be any imbalance in the provision of information. My question was, if I asked for it would I get it, and they said no. When the Resource Assessment Commission has concluded its consideration of the information, it will be available for us all.

—I thank Senator McMullan for setting that matter to rest-I hope it will set the matter to rest. I note that he says the report will be made available in November, after the next Estimates that this Committee will consider-because I expect that will be around September or October. If that is what Senator McMullan is saying, it really means that this matter will not be subject to further scrutiny until April or May of next year, in almost 12 months time. I would rather hope that the results may come out before the next Estimates so that the matter can be properly considered. I will take Senator McMullan's undertaking at face value and look forward to receiving the information as soon as it becomes available. The question I now ask is: why was there no member of the Resource Assessment Commission present who knew anything about the survey at all?

—I understand that the problem was a misunderstanding as to the survey to which Senator O'Chee was referring. People thought that he was referring to the infamous Kakadu contingent value survey, about which I am delighted that I do not have to answer any questions.

—That is certainly not the case. I know that Senator McMullan was not there, but it was made very clear to the officers at the hearing that we were talking about a postal survey in relation to the timber industry. They raised the matter of the Kakadu National Park. I certainly did not. To ascribe to me the red herring that the departmental officers raised is very cunning of the departmental officers but not satisfactory. In some ways I find it disrespectful to the Senate that the departmental officers should try to ascribe to me their own misunderstanding and their failure to be able to come to grips with the fact that there was a survey. The departmental officer who was present at the Estimates that evening said to me that he did not know of any postal surveys. Why did the departmental officer not know of any postal surveys?

—I do not have anything to add. If the officer in question was confused or misunderstood, that is all that can be said. We have now given the most comprehensive reply we can to Senator O'Chee. If the delay since 23 April has caused him some inconvenience, I regret that. But now before the Senate we have given the information. That is the only answer I can give. There is nothing I can add. I cannot say, `Let us go back to 23 April and start again'. That is all the information I can give to Senator O'Chee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be watching out for that departmental officer very closely. In fact, I will be looking at the entire Resource Assessment Commission the next time we come to Estimates later this year. Certainly I did not find the conduct of either that departmental officer or the people who appeared on behalf of the Resource Assessment Commission satisfactory. I am making that comment now so that it is recorded in Hansard and so that the departmental officers are fully on notice that they should expect a question relating to any activities that they have been undertaking. The performance to date has not been satisfactory.

SPEECH.PARA: I have one final series of questions in relation to this matter. I understand that the survey had a bar code on the back. In the answer provided by the Resource Assessment Commission to the question it took on notice, I am told that the bar code was used to follow up the questionnaires that went out and, in particular, the respondents who did not answer the questionnaire. The answer to my question on notice indicated that the particular matching of bar codes and respondents' names and addresses was destroyed. I am very concerned that respondents did not know, or were not told at the time at which they received the questionnaire, that the questionnaire contained a bar code which would be used to follow up their lack of response.

I am also concerned that at no stage was any indication given to the respondents that any possible matching of information would be destroyed. I am still not absolutely satisfied that respondents to this questionnaire can rest easy. I suppose it is difficult to prove that either way. I want it noted that this caused a great deal of anxiety to people. They received letters which, irrespective of whether they were intended to be intimidatory, were certainly perceived as being intimidatory. It upset respondents. On the whole it was very unsatisfactory. The manner in which the survey was conducted, the nature of the letters and the persistent way in which they were received by the respondents caused a great deal of upset. Unless it is absolutely and critically important to the survey, I would certainly be recommending that that sort of approach not occur again because of the great degree of concern it caused people who had received the questionnaire and who were, after all, sampled at random.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In general I want to make two points regarding those comments. The first regards the nature of the letters and the conduct of the survey overall. I have not seen the letters, although I have had some briefing on the way the survey was conducted. Australia has a well developed body of market research companies and consultancies which conduct researches such as this in a reputable manner and have done so consistently over time. Although I have not had dealings with the company concerned in this instance, I know well that the consultant on the design and analysis of the survey, Professor McAllister, is a thoroughly reputable individual.

SPEECH.PARA: On the written information I have had, I believe that the survey was conducted entirely properly and with propriety. I acknowledge what Senator O'Chee says. When people receive the most innocent of letters from government, they find it very alarming. A person will ask, `Why has the Government written to me about this?' If the Department of Social Security writes to people and says, `Your pension has gone up', they worry and seek advice about what this letter really means for them. I do understand that letters that come directly and indirectly from government bodies have to be more sensitive than others. That is a matter that ought properly to be taken into account in future.

Although I have not personally supervised the destruction of the documents, I suggest that there is a much more productive use of both the time of Senator O'Chee and the Senate than conspiracies about whether individuals have kept information or whether a research consultancy, which would have no possibly sensible use for it, has kept information. That is a fairly unnecessary slur to which I would not want to give too much credence. I accept that the material is being destroyed, firstly, because I have been told so by reputable people and, secondly, because I cannot see why people would want to keep it. The information that has been extracted from it is all that people would reasonably want. It is important that surveys such as this are conducted in accordance with proper standards. I have no reason to believe that this one was not, but it is important that we ensure that they are.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to set the record straight. I was not saying that the information had been kept; I was just recording the particular constituents' concern that it may have been kept. I am very grateful for the undertaking that Senator McMullan has provided that the information has been destroyed. I accept Senator McMullan's undertaking as I have accepted his other undertakings. I have no further questions on this matter.
—We will now move on to the Department of the Treasury.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As was the case with Senator Bishop in relation to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, in view of the very tight time limit we have, I will restrict my questions on the Department of the Treasury to the two or three that I regard as more important. Firstly, I may require Senator McMullan's indulgence in terms of where this issue fits in with the report. It is an issue that I think has to be raised in this context and I hope he will allow me the necessary licence.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter I raise relates to an issue that has arisen since the Estimates committee hearings; that is, the release of statistics by the Australian Bureau of Statistics last week in relation to payments of taxes, fees and fines per head of population in each of the States. Senator McMullan will be aware, no doubt, that the statistics released on 24 May contained a very significant error in relation to the statistics for the State of New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short, I draw your attention to the fact that I cannot find anything in either the report or the supplementary papers which would indicate that you would have the opportunity to ask questions about this. Since you indicated that you were going to stick primarily to the key issues and were not going to ask a lot of irrelevant questions, you could seek the leave of the Committee. I presume Senator McMullan would have no objections to answering that question. It is entirely up to the Committee to give you leave.
—I was asking for a little indulgence, however, I seek leave.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The figures released last week by the Australian Bureau of Statistics contained an error in relation to New South Wales. There was an overstatement of New South Wales tax revenue of $269m for the year 1989-90. That was the amount of payroll tax paid by government agencies. The Bureau has since admitted its error and published a revised figure, but I would seek some explanation as to how such a very important and gross error could possibly have occurred in the figures.
—I am sure that neither Senator Short nor Senator Walters is implying it was done deliberately.
—Maybe.

—Perhaps I am not correct in making that assumption. But I believe it is correct. I am sorry that there are no Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) officers here to give Senator Short the information. However, I understand the importance of the question-not only because of its particular political sensitivity on the day but also because we all have to depend on the accuracy of ABS data for our economic analysis of these and other matters. I will get an answer for Senator Short as soon as I can but, I am sorry to say, I cannot do it tonight.

-I make the point that, when the error was detected, the Premier of New South Wales said, `I'm not suggesting that the Statistician is part of any terrible plot by Mr Keating to help the New South Wales Labor Party and to help his leadership bid next Tuesday'-which is today- `because I've got no basis for saying it'. So the Premier acknowledged that point, but he did go on to say, and I endorse it, `It is a disgrace, in my view, that the Bureau got that figure so wrong at such a politically critical time'. Again, Senator McMullan will probably have to take this on notice, but I want to know why those figures were released at all two days before such a critically important political event when, as I understand it, going back to the last five years, the corresponding figures in 1986 were released on 7 April; in 1987 on 9 April; in 1988 on 15 April; in 1989 on 17 February; and in 1990 on 11 April. It would appear that the release of the figures was running late anyway. How anyone could have had the naivety to have released those figures-I use the word `naivety' generously-particularly with the possibility of errors in them, at such a critically important time is a very serious matter. No doubt we on this side of the chamber will want to take up that issue in due course when the explanations that Senator McMullan has sought are forthcoming. On behalf of the coalition I want to record our extreme concern about this matter.

—by leave-As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) has said, this is a particularly important issue. He said that because we did not give any forewarning, he does not have the officers present at the moment. Seeing that we have to consider the report of Estimates Committee A after 8 o'clock, could the officers be available after that time so they can deal with this issue? I believe it is extremely important that both we and the public understand why the figures were released. An explanation has to be given as to how the error came to be made. I do not think it is asking too much to bring an officer back, seeing as we are to consider the report of Estimates Committee A after 8 o'clock.

—In response to what Senator Short said about timing, if there had been some unwarranted, deliberate delay in the presentation of the information, I think that would be cause for concern. But once the information is in the hands of the Australian Bureau of Statistics and available for release, the question of timing is not an appropriate one for criticism. Had it had the information on the Friday and chosen not to release it until the Monday, we would have had equal controversy. I think it has to release the information when it has it. I will ensure that the timing of the release of the information is part of the response that comes back. I will inquire whether an appropriate officer is available. But given there was no warning we may not have an officer who can give the appropriate information at 8 o'clock. If not, I will provide an answer to the chamber as soon as I can get one-promptly.

—If the officer is not available to attend tonight, I ask Senator McMullan whether, when his information comes to us, the officer will be available. I acknowledge that there could be equal criticism of figures that were already delayed not being made available as soon as they were available. The first announcement of that gross error was made on the 10.30 news on Friday night. I felt that other steps that could have been taken to make the public aware of the gross error were not taken and, therefore, I would like to ask questions of the officer concerned. Senator McMullan knows how difficult it will be if he comes back with an answer and we have questions that flow on from that answer. So I would appreciate it if that officer could be made available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Others are more experienced than I in this. Other than at the Estimates Committee itself, I am not sure that it is appropriate that the officer be called upon to provide the answer. The accountability to the Parliament is for Ministers or, in my case, the quasi half Minister. I will undertake to provide an answer. I will have a look at that question. I am not saying no; I do not want to give a guarantee one way or another because it is the first time that sort of question has crossed my desk.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that it is also a question to which an answer will be available at full Estimates Committee hearings, if at no other time. It is not an attempt to hide the information; it is a question of going through the proper procedures.
