I will do that and make sure that the information is available comprehensively and in a way that facilitates discussion by this chamber. I do not want to go into any more detail than that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish simply to endorse Senator Walters's request and would ask Senator McMullan to see what he can do about it. I would have thought that it should be possible. There are a couple of hours left in tonight's debate, and at this time of the year and at this time of the night people do not stray too far from Canberra. Senator McMullan might think about setting such a request in train.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to just how significant this error was, I want to put it on record that the effect of the error was to show New South Wales as a higher taxing State than other States. In fact, had that error not occurred, the increase in taxes and revenue in New South Wales for 1989-90 would have been shown as the lowest percentage increase of any State at a figure of six per cent. Not only that, but the fact of the matter is that when the Greiner Government came to office average tax rates in New South Wales were 4.6 per cent above those in the other States. In 1989-90, the year in which the error occurred, New South Wales tax rates were down to only 0.2 per cent above the average of other States. Indeed, there is a very strong probability that when the figures become available for 1990-91 the New South Wales figures will be below the average of the other States. The New South Wales record over the past three years far outstrips that of any State in that department.

I want to raise a matter relating to the questions that had not been answered at the conclusion of our hearings about act of grace and ex gratia payments. Senator McMullan will recall that various questions were asked by both Senator Bishop and me in that regard as far as they may relate to Mr Burke, and other issues came up as well. In the Estimates Committee it was said that, if Mr Burke's termination payment-at that stage Mr Burke's date of termination was effective from 31 July; since then the resignation date has become effective immediately-came under the normal severance provisions of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Department of Finance would not be involved; it would be involved only if an act of grace payment were made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this Treasury or the Department of Finance?

—The Department of Finance. As far as the Department of the Treasury is concerned, I have a follow-up question to an answer that has been given to me by the Australian Taxation Office in response to the question on notice as at the end of the Estimates hearings. I had asked about the level of tax expenditure arising from union dues being tax deductible.

SPEECH.PARA: The answer I received to that was that the most recent year for which deductions for subscriptions to trade unions, et cetera were separately recorded was 1986-87 and that the statistics relate to subscriptions to trade, business or professional associations. I was told in answer that `for 1986-87, total deductions for subscriptions to trade, business or professional associations amounted to $377m and the cost to revenue was $162m'. I ask whether the Taxation Office has a breakdown of those subscriptions and deductions and the cost to revenue on the basis of trade, business or professional associations.

TALK.START.PARA: —No; it is all in one category in the tax return. It is not broken down separately.

—Does that mean that the Australian Taxation Office does not maintain records in such a way that if I were to ask a question, as I did, as to the level of taxation from union dues being tax deductible, that figure is unattainable because it is so merged with dues paid by other organisations? Is there no separate identification of trade unions on the one hand and professional organisations or business associations on the other hand?
—On my understanding, yes.

—I must say that I find that extraordinary, given the amount of money we spend on recording tax collections and tax data. I find it totally extraordinary that that information is unrecorded on a separate basis when it is, I would think for many people, a matter for considerable interest. I presume that Senator McMullan is confirming what he just said.

—Yes, I am. Let me explain why in a little detail. I am not confessing great expertise in this matter but, as Senator Short would understand, as I am advised and as I recall it, there is a question on the individual tax return which has three categories of trade, business or professional association, individual rights in the association, and the amount. The Australian Taxation Office would key in that yes, the person made a claim under that category and that it was a claim for X. There would be no reason for the Tax Office to key into the overall records which of those three categories it came in. One would have to go back through all of the nine million or so forms and hand tabulate them, asking, `Which category does this particular person's claim come under?'. Some people may claim under more than one category. It is not the sort of information that would readily come out of the normal processing of a tax return form.

—I take it that all associations, trade unions or any other organisations submit taxation returns as do individuals. Therefore, in the normal course of returns, would not an amount of income that, say, an individual trade union or an individual professional association had received by way of subscriptions from its members be available to the Australian Taxation Office? Would that be correct?
—Trade unions are exempt from income tax. They do not submit income tax returns, as far as I know.
—That is only as to self-funding of investment income.
—Is it the case that under no circumstances trade unions file tax returns?

—I do not want to give a legal opinion but they would not submit one that provided information to the Australian Taxation Office which indicated, in a manner that it would wish to store, the amount of revenue gained from membership subscriptions, which is the point that Senator Short is pursuing.

—I wish to pursue Senator Short's point. In relation to the question of membership fees, trade unions would be in the same position as political parties in that an organisation cannot make money out of itself. The principle of mutuality applies. Would Senator McMullan agree with that?
—That is not the situation with regard to trade unions.
—So if they owned an operating services company, would that services company be required to file a tax return?

—The trade unions' exemption does not operate on the basis of mutuality, as political parties do in the way that Senator Bishop correctly described. Income of trade unions and associations of employers registered under any industrial relations law is exempt from income tax. It is specifically provided by section 23f of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Therefore, they do not pay tax on their income, whether it is received from subscriptions or otherwise.

—The second part of my question did not relate to that. Should those trade union organisations, or employer organisations for that matter, set up a services company, an operating company, which may carry out various services for them for one reason and other, I presume that would have to be disclosed; that company would have to file a tax return. I wonder whether the nexus would be shown.

—Hypothetical questions do not take us far, but this might be more useful. If the income is income of the trade union or the employers association, it is exempt. If it is income from a body which does not constitute an association of employers or employees registered under an arbitration Act, it is not exempt. I do not want to get into a case of whether A or B would be exempt, because that is a matter for legal opinion or interpretation by the Commissioner. I can only tell Senator Bishop what the law says: if the income is the income of an association of employers or employees, then it will be exempt; if it is not that body's income, then it will not be exempt. It will depend upon the nature of that holding company and its relationship with the income. If the income constituted a separately registered body that was not an association of employees or employers, of course it would not be exempt. If it was nominal and the income became income of the trade union in some manner-and it is not for me to speculate about why-then it would be exempt. The law is fairly clear.

—Supposing we had a hypothetical case: two trade unionists established a company, that company received donations, and that company paid money. Maybe they invested the donations; maybe interest was paid on it; or maybe they chose to simply hand over some of that money. If such a company existed and individuals or corporations made donations to that company, and that company paid all or any of that money or its income investment back to the trade union, firstly, would that be treated as money of the trade union; secondly, would it be required to file a taxation return; and, thirdly, what would its status be for the purposes of so-called future transparent and total disclosure of any donations-bearing in mind it could be acting as a warehouse, perhaps for the Australian Labor Party?
—That is a pretty transparent question. If Senator Bishop wants a legal opinion about hypothetical tax situations, she should put them on notice and I will try to get answers for her.
—I would be delighted if Senator McMullan would take it on notice.

—To confirm my understanding, if a trade union or an employer organisation sets up a business to make steel and that company is 100 per cent owned by that union or association, and that business was successful and made $100m a year, is the income from that operation totally exempt?

—Senator Short is stretching the bounds of hypothesis extraordinarily, but if at the end of the day one is able to interpret that body as an association of employers or employees, then section 23f of the Income Tax Assessment Act would apply to it. I imagine that that particular body would have a pretty rough time with the Commissioner of Taxation establishing that it was such. If the Commissioner of Taxation or whichever tribunal this was contested before decided that the company did constitute an association of employees or employers, then it would be exempt. If they were not able to be convinced, then it would be not be exempt-which is the answer to Senator Bishop's previous question.

—I will not pursue it any further other than to say that I do not think it is really a hypothetical situation. The ability of such associations to run a business at profit might be hypothetical. We have had numerous examples over recent years of businesses, particularly with the Australian Council of Trade Unions running businesses-ACTU Solo; the Burke stores in Melbourne; and a travel agency business. So it is by no means a hypothetical example. There have been real life situations and I am sure there will be more in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question which relates to any outcome from the inquiries we made concerning disclosure of confidential information by the Australian Taxation Office. I ask for any further information in the context of the answers that were provided on page 136 and 137 of volume two of Estimates Committee A Additional Information. The answer reads:

SPEECH.PARA: During the current financial year there have been 47 allegations of leaking or sale of information (three involving sale) . . . . 19 cases have been found worthy of further investigation.

In two cases, no offence was found; in two cases, disciplinary action was taken; in two cases, the offenders were arrested by the Australian Federal Police; and one case has been referred to the Australian Federal Police. In the previous two financial years, nine cases were referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions for prosecution. Convictions were secured in two of them, with one officer imprisoned and another fined; six cases are awaiting result; in two cases, disciplinary action was taken; no offences were found in 15 cases; and in 19 cases, insufficient evidence was found.

I would like details of the degree of seriousness and details of the cases where the Australian Federal Police is involved and where convictions have been involved. I would like to know whether or not the matters that we dealt with, and which are referred in the reservation to the Estimates Committee report, relate to any of those cases referred to in the answers or whether they are separate. If they are separate, what action is being taken?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not got anything at the moment to add to that which was provided in the answer to which Senator Bishop referred. I will see what further information is available in regard to both her general and specific points and, to the extent there is anything further, I will make it available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek a further explanation on the cost of the tax modernisation project of the Australian Taxation Office referred to in the Estimates A report. The answers that I received from the Taxation Office about this matter have certainly shed light on the cost of the modernisation project. However, I want to point out that this is the first time, and only as a result of the special questioning that we undertook in Senate Estimates committees, that it has been possible to obtain the information on the cost of this modernisation project.

SPEECH.PARA: Neither the Budget Papers of 1988-89 nor the Budget Papers of 1990-91 provided detailed information on the reasons for the increase in costs of the modernisation program. I think that reflects very badly on the Government's preparation of Budget Papers, particularly on the Department of Finance which prepares statement three of Budget Paper No. 1. The 1991 Budget Papers prepared by the Taxation Office last year are full of detail of a descriptive nature about the modernisation program but contain no hard facts on the actual costs to be incurred.

As a result of the questioning that we have undertaken in Senate Estimates, for the first time we have an easy identification of the increased costs-we are talking about $750m-expected over the life of this project. We now know what that comprises, but nowhere in the Budget Papers can that be found in its entirety. I would like an explanation of why the Budget Papers do not contain sufficient information-in fact, almost none at all-on the escalation of the cost for this project.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the order agreed to earlier this day, the Committee will resume consideration of the estimates of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. I understand that honourable senators have particular questions relating to Austrade and the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation. The question is that the report of Estimates Committee A as it relates to this Bill be adopted.

—The particular questions I want to ask with regard to Austrade relate to a matter that I raised in Estimates Committee A concerning the building of a boat for one Mr Cantor. An $8m loan was given to this gentleman. Dr Fisher told us about the new security measures that are in place at Austrade as a result of a $16m rip-off, and I asked whether or not Mr Cantor would get in the door again. I wanted an assurance that we would not be doing business with an associate of the Mafia. I did not receive that assurance. Subsequently, I ascertained that the amount of money involved was not $8m but, in fact, $16m. At the outset, I ask whether the Minister can give me details about the $3m bounty payment that was made in addition to any other amounts of money from Austrade.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not a matter which relates to the Austrade estimates. It is paid for under the shipbuilding bounty legislation.
—It was, in fact, $3m that was paid, was it?
—I cannot tell Senator Bishop the precise amount, but whatever was paid would have been paid under that legislation.

—Perhaps the Minister could find out and confirm for me that it was, in fact, $3m. I now refer to the payments directly from Austrade. Firstly, when inquiries were made about Mr Cantor, were they sufficient to show that in 1980 Mr Cantor had been involved with Vosper Thorneycroft in the United Kingdom and that he had perpetrated a similar deceit upon that company regarding the building of a boat called Jeanette? Did Austrade's inquiries discover that?
—No, Austrade was unaware of that at the relevant time.

—Although the Minister's officers probably cannot tell us tonight, perhaps the Minister could tell us the nature of the inquiries that Austrade or the Export Finance Insurance Corporation (EFIC) conducted in order to ascertain whether Mr Cantor was a suitable person for a Government agency to be doing business with. Can the Minister ask EFIC to detail for us the inquiries that it did conduct?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that this was fully dealt with by Dr Fisher during the course of the Estimates Committee.

—With respect, it was not. I will ask the Minister again later. I will move on. Dr Fisher told us that the contracts were signed with Mr Cantor prior to Austrade or EFIC becoming aware of the fact that Mr Cantor was arrested. I am informed that that is not so. In fact, the agreement was signed some months afterwards. The arrest was in May 1987 and the documents were not signed until October 1987. Will the Minister confirm whether that is true?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the commitment to make a loan was made prior to Mr Cantor's arrest, and when his arrest came to the knowledge of Austrade, EFIC the organisation, sought legal advice as to whether it could withdraw from the commitment and was told no.
—I wonder if we could have that advice tabled.
—I think it most unlikely. It is probably a matter that is--
—You are not going to tell me that it is commercial-in-confidence, are you?

—In the generic sense it is, because everybody who goes to EFIC for finance purposes has documents which are put before the organisation which they would not want to be discussed in public, whether that be in a legal opinion or otherwise.

—I am sure that we do not have too many clients who are connected with the Gambino family-or I hope we do not. I would have thought that when we are dealing with someone with a connection with the Mafia, we would be most interested to see what sort of legal advice we got which said that we had to comply with some sort of obligation that we had to that person. Would the Minister confirm to me that the arrest was in May 1987 and the documents were not signed until October 1987?
—I have already done that in answer to a previous question.

—I thank the Minister. If I missed it, I am pleased that he has reaffirmed it. I ask the Minister again whether we could have that legal advice tendered, please. I really do not think that commercial-in-confidence applies to Mafiosa.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —That, ultimately, is a matter for me to decide and I will certainly look at the issue. I can foreshadow my likely decision which is that that will not be available.
—We might have to pursue that in another way. I really did not think that the Minister was one who would protect such a person. I wonder if the Minister could tell me about the $2.5m--
—I raise a point of order, Mr Chairman. I object to that.
—Yes, I think you should rightly object to it. The imputation against Senator Button should be withdrawn, Senator Bishop.
—I withdraw any imputation that Senator Button drew from my remarks.
—That is not satisfactory. You made an imputation about Senator Button, you know what the imputation was and I ask you to withdraw it.
—Mr Chairman, you give me the words and I will say them.
—Senator Bishop, there was an imputation against Senator Button--
—Mr Chairman, I withdraw any imputation in whatever terms you are expressing it.
—Mr Chairman, that is not good enough for me.
—Let the Minister give me the words he would like.

—The imputation was that because I may exercise my judgment in a particular way to protect documents that I regard as confidential-and I have not made a decision about that yet-I would be doing that to protect a person who is a member of the Mafia. That is the imputation which I seek to have withdrawn.
—Is the imputation that he is a member of the Mafia, or that the Minister would chose to do it?
—Don't ask me. You ought to know.

—I am sorry, but if the Minister is saying that he will not release those documents because they are commercial-in-confidence and because he wishes to protect this man, that is not an imputation, it is simply a matter of fact.
—Senator Bishop, I rule that it is an imputation, and I ask you to withdraw it unconditionally.

—Whatever the imputation is, I withdraw it. I refer to the $2.5m raised by the company building the boat, Runmere, guaranteed by the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation, which enabled the construction of the boat to continue. Will the Minister confirm that that payment was made, and the date?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, payment was made. I cannot give the date.
—I thank the Minister. Could he provide the date if it cannot be supplied now?
—I will have to supply the date at a later stage.
—The next payment I would like confirmed is the $2.3m paid by EFIC in the form of a performance bond.
—Is the honourable senator asking the question in respect of this transaction?
—Indeed. All these questions relate to this transaction.
—Yes.
—It was $2.3m, not $2.5m?
—It was $US1.75m.
—Could the Minister tell me what that amount translates into and the date that the payment was made?
—It is quite impossible for me to do that. My mathematics are impeccably bad. The facility was made available in United States dollars.
—If we could have the date, we would know how much that translates into. Could we have the date?
—I have already said that we will obtain the date.
—This is with respect to the second date; $US1.75m and the date to be supplied. Perhaps the Minister could confirm that $A1m of that was for an engine for Hastings Deering?
—I will confirm a number of these things at the one time.

—Perhaps when the Minister is confirming things he will confirm that, at the time of the liquidation of Runmere, which was forced to the wall over this contract, in fact there was a claim for $6m against Cantor in the name of Runmere for charges to the contract but in fact EFIC is not prosecuting the claim for $6m. Perhaps the Minister could say why he is not prosecuting that claim?
—EFIC is not a party to that contract. It has no standing to prosecute anything. The liquidator was the one who decided not to prosecute.

—EFIC would have a good interest in the matter. Could we find out, firstly, who is the liquidator and, secondly, why the liquidator has decided not to press the claim? Certainly EFIC would have a great interest in recovering $6m or a share thereof, I would have thought.
—Yes.
—Is that an indication that the Minister will find out?
—We will do our best.

—I wonder also whether the Minister could confirm that Trade Commissioner Colin Williams in fact informed Mr Fisher, who informed Mr Saunders of Runmere, that indeed the bragging going around New York by Mr Cantor was that he was having a boat built, courtesy of the Australian Government, worth $25m of which the Australian Government had provided $16m?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not a matter that relates to the Estimates. If Mr Cantor is a braggart, that is something that can be dealt with elsewhere, not here.

—If the Minister adds up all those amounts which he admits have in fact been paid, the $16m would seem to be an accurate sum. It would seem there is a possibility of getting some of it back, yet no action has been taken to do that. I refer to the evidence that Dr Fisher gave us that Mr Cantor was paying all his bills. I ask the Minister whether he can give an assurance, as the Minister who will continue to be responsible for EFIC, that the likes of Mr Cantor will never darken his doorstep again.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that there is ongoing legal action against the directors of Runmere who gave personal guarantees. That legal action is taking place at present.

—The Minister will be amazed if I do not find that terribly assuring. Runmere are the people who have been squeezed by the shonky dealings of these smart people from New York, including the lawyer who went in and took initial possession of the shipyard and, as I understand it, has gone off-shore again, and the Minister will persecute or prosecute the poor old Australians who have gone to the wall. At the same time, I presume that Mr Cantor has his $25m boat; is that true? How much has Mr Cantor repaid? Is it a fact that Mr Cantor has possession of the boat?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Mr Cantor has the boat which is mortgaged to EFIC. The action against the other directors of Runmere is made on the basis of personal guarantees which they gave in respect of this transaction.

—The mortgage is to the tune of $8m, not $16m. He has it for eight years at 8 per cent. We were told that that was a perfectly normal rate in the boat building industry. Has Mr Cantor possession of that boat and, if so, where is it?
—I have already answered that.
—Is the Minister saying that Mr Cantor has possession of the boat?
—Yes, I have already answered that.
—Where is the boat?
—I have no idea.
—Does EFIC have any idea where this mortgaged boat is?
—Brisbane.
—It is currently in Brisbane?
—Yes.
—Has it been attached or does Mr Cantor still have control of the vessel?
—No, it is his boat. It has not been attached.

—So he can have the boat forever as long as he meets his payments to honour the $8m loan, the documentation for which was signed after he was arrested on charges of having defrauded the trustee in the United States, and that was signed on the basis of a legal opinion which we may or may not be able to see. Is that a fairly accurate summation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Like many of the honourable senator's summations, it is half correct.
—Which half?

—Let me say that she is right in saying that as long as Mr Cantor makes his payments, he has the boat. That part of the summation is correct. In so far as it is an eight year loan at a rate of 8 per cent, that is normal, as the honourable senator implied in the question which she asked.
—And what the Minister told me in Estimates.
—That is excellent; that is a good thing to do.
—The Minister said that my summation was half right. I am asking which half was wrong?
—The other half!
—The half other than the half which I mentioned relating to the terms of repayment, the interest rate and the fact that, as long as Mr Cantor makes his payments, he is entitled to have the boat.

—The rest of it was that he has the boat because the Minister signed the documentation after his arrest on the recommendation of a legal opinion which we may or may not see. I take it that it was from the Attorney-General's Department or the Crown Solicitor?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator is right in most of what she has said. A legal opinion was obtained after the contract had been signed. The contract was signed after Mr Cantor had been arrested. I have answered all those questions in the course of my earlier remarks. In fact, there were two contributors to the legal advice: one a US lawyer and the other, EFIC's general counsel.
—One United States lawyer. Was that Mr Cantor's lawyer by any chance-the one who went into possession when Runmere went into liquidation?
—No, Senator.
—Who was it? Why did the Minister seek an American lawyer's opinion?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —It was done in order to have United States advice in case there were protests from Mr Cantor about the nature of advice received in Australia. It was complementary advice, if you like.
—Did the Minister seek it and pay for it or was it Mr Cantor's advice?
—No, it was EFIC's advice. I have answered that question.

—To the contrary, the Minister says things such as telling me that my summation was half right but he then went on to tell me that it was in fact 100 per cent right. Forgive me for pursuing a question more than once. Who was the American lawyer from whom the advice was obtained?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, I will not forgive Senator Bishop for pursuing a subject more than once because in earlier questions about this matter I answered the question about when the contract was signed. I explained to the honourable senator that a commitment regarding this loan was entered into before Mr Cantor was arrested in America and that legal advice was to the effect that the commitment could not be broken. I have answered all of those parts of the question. So I am afraid I cannot forgive the honourable senator for reiterating this issue again and again. In so far as the name of the lawyer is concerned, that is a matter which I will have to determine in light of deciding whether I will provide the opinion.
—Who is EFIC's general counsel?
—Mrs Carol Flanagan.
—Where is she from? Is she in private practice? Is she at the Bar? Is she employed as a Government solicitor?
—She is from the EFIC.
—I see, she is an in-house lawyer. Could you describe Mrs Carol Flanagan's level of employment within EFIC?
—Let us get some order back into this. We have been having cross-fire for the last 15 minutes. I ask honourable senators not to speak until I call them.
—She is a general counsel for EFIC.

—We are talking about $16m. The Minister was pretty appalled in the Estimates Committee hearing when we dealt with the first scam for $16m. The Minister said that Austrade had been the butt of a very clever group of people who had defrauded it and EFIC. We now find a man who has been even more blatant. Had the Government not gone ahead and lent him $8m, all we might have been up for was $8m instead of $16m. The next question I ask is: was any or all of the money paid over before the documentation was signed?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want the honourable senator's verbosity to lead anybody in the Committee to the conclusion that I agree with anything she is saying. This is not a scam; it would become a scam if the loan were not repaid. But to make it a scam on this tenuous set of connections-that Mr Cantor appears, on the basis of some American experience, to be a person of questionable character-is purely in the realms of allegation, not in the realms of question in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, but we are talking about $16m of taxpayers' money, $8m of which is secured. We are talking about the largess of giving away taxpayers' dollars-$3m by way of bounty and another $5m by way of other payments. We are talking about the failure of Austrade and/or EFIC to do proper investigations to find out the background of this man when I have already told the Minister that if they had looked back they could have found that he did exactly the same sort of thing in 1980 and sent boat builders to the wall then.

SPEECH.PARA: The only solace the Minister can give me is that the Australian Government via EFIC will try to persecute some Australian builders of the boat who were taken in by this man and who have been sent to the wall. The Government is going to try to screw them for their guarantees. In the meantime, Mr Cantor has a $25m boat which he enjoys the fruits of and he boasts around New York that he has it courtesy of the Australian Government. I ask the Minister: does he think that is a suitable situation for the Australian Government to be involved in?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —In so far as the EFIC moneys constituted a loan, we have no reason to believe that they will not be paid back. The fact that they have to be paid back over eight years is nothing abnormal.
—That is half of it.

—Yes. In respect of the other half which related to working capital, procedures are being taken to recover that amount. It is all very exciting, I know, but it is slightly premature to be going on about this until those proceedings are concluded and until there is a default under the loan-if there is a default. The honourable senator began this latest question-not question, speech, if I might say so-by referring to Government largess in providing money to this ship building facility. Firstly, let me say that the Government largess, as the honourable senator calls it, is not any strange or silly hand-out. The bounty payment is made under legislation passed by this Parliament, for which Senator Bishop voted, and it is made in accordance with that legislation. So let us not get too carried away with that particular aspect of the largess. In so far as there is an alleged failure of Austrade and EFIC, this allegation is a little premature.

—From the Minister's own lips we heard that the only joy that the Government will get for the remaining $8m is to take on those directors of the struggling company which was trying to build this boat, and the Minister may care to go through the difficulties that they had with regard to a smart New York lawyer changing the terms of the contract and making them bear the costs. Does the Minister think that anyone will get any joy out of thinking we may get back some of the money which the Government has paid out by selling up ordinary Australians' houses in Brisbane so that the Government can get a measly few hundred thousand dollars in the kick, when in fact all Mr Cantor-the man connected with the Gambino family-has to do is keep up his repayments over eight years at 8 per cent and he has a boat worth $25m, of which the Australian Government and taxpayers have kicked in a further $8m? Is the Minister really telling me that he thinks that EFIC and Austrade have done a good job?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have said on a number of occasions, it remains to be seen. In so far as this Parramatta police court case you make about the guarantees, these people signed and entered into guarantees.
—What is the extent of their assets?

—That is something which was done to help secure these moneys. The outcome of those proceedings is not yet known. In so far as the alleged connections with the mafia of a man who bought a boat from a shipyard in Brisbane which were discovered subsequently by Austrade and Senator Bishop, that is an unfortunate circumstance about which we cannot draw many conclusions at this stage.

—Could the Minister please have the officers explain to us what the asset backing is of the directors who gave the guarantees? What degree of investigation was conducted by Austrade into the value of those guarantees?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that, at the time the guarantees were given, inquiries were made about the guarantors, and EFIC at that time was satisfied with the substance of the guarantors.

—I asked what was the extent of their asset banking. If one is to accept that a guarantee has any worth, one wants to know what a person owns. I want to know whether they owned any more than their boat building business and their own houses and cars. Perhaps the officers would be good enough to let us have a list of the assets of the guarantors and/or to tell us whether they ever asked or whether it was simply a formality.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already answered that question. I do not think the guarantors of the loan in Brisbane would be pleased to have all their business discussed in this chamber and I certainly do not propose to indulge in that. It may be all rather fun, but it is not very nice for them, I suspect.

SPEECH.PARA: The loan which is creating so much excitement at the moment is one out of $23.8 billion worth of exports supported by EFIC over the past five financial years. I must say that, if the worst came to the worst, it would be unsatisfactory, but the worst has not come to the worst at this stage. But it is a very small amount in terms of the business which is done by EFIC in support of Australian exporters. We dealt with this in the context of the Estimates Committee, and I do not have terribly much more to add. It would be unfortunate if the honourable senator's direst predictions came true, but I think it is too early to make them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Contrary to the Minister's prognostications about how willing the directors of Runmere would be to have their matters discussed in the Senate, they are appalled about what has happened to them and what the Australian Government is doing to them. Ordinary Australians out there are pretty appalled that the Minister thinks it okay to lose $32m over a couple of years because in the context of billions it really does not matter.

SPEECH.PARA: An ordinary Australian, suffering under this recession we had to have, trying to make his mortgage payments, minds about it a hell of a lot. I know that the Minister is laid back and likes to have that laconic attitude, but we are talking about taxpayers' money-not Government money. Government does not have any money. It is taxpayers' money. I asked this of the Minister before. I wanted to be assured that the likes of Mr Cantor would never get in the front door again, and I still have not had that assurance. Do we get it now?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —All sorts of things waste taxpayers' money, including the numerous hours which the Estimates Committee spent, and which the chamber is now spending again, on the same issues.
—With this Government, you bet.
—Order!
—It was a very mild interjection.
—It was not a mild rebuke.

—What EFIC or any organisation has to do is as best it can to exercise due diligence about the people to whom it makes loans. It does that with an enormously successful internationally recognised record. If Senator Bishop wants to ask me questions I will try to answer them, but I do not propose to respond to every speech she makes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that the Executive of this Government regards the Parliament with contempt and finds it most inconvenient to be accountable to it. However, under our system of democracy, until such time as the Government replaces it by banning the publicity of the freely spoken word or any other means it chooses to use, the Government, in its expenditure of public money via its agencies, is accountable to this Parliament. Its disdain, contempt, laconic humour or anything else will not change the fact that it is accountable to this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister again: will he assure this Parliament that he will not put at risk more millions of taxpayers' dollars by allowing EFIC and Austrade to be conducted in such a slack manner as he has allowed them to be in doing business with the likes of Mr Cantor? Can I have that assurance?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know of any others in the Opposition who feel that I regard them with contempt. It may be a case of, `If the cap fits, wear it.' I do not know of anybody who feels that way. First of all, the fundamental premise in this allegation is that we are talking about taxpayers' money. We are not.
—Oh yes, we are.

—It was explained to Senator Bishop very carefully in the Estimates Committee, but she chose to ignore it. There is a fundamentally wrong premise in what she is putting. It is not taxpayers' money. The fine speeches are a lot of fun, but they are really not relevant to the point she is trying to make.

—The Minister should tell me and the Australians who provide the money that goes into the kitty and is then spent on behalf of Austrade and EFIC in the salaries that are paid and the offices that are rented-the whole box and dice-whether those costs come out of public funds. Indeed, he can say all he likes-that he has pushed it off Budget; that it is not in a public arena; that it is some sort of quasi-private endeavour-but, until such time as it is privatised, and then he would have a case, it is accountable to the Parliament. I would still like the assurance that we will not be doing business with the likes of Mr Cantor, and still the Minister will not give that me that assurance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have said on a number of occasions, and I do not propose to say it more than once more, that an organisation such as EFIC has to exercise due diligence in what it does. It has been enormously successful in doing that. It is very careful to see that the loans which are made are capable of being repaid in an appropriate manner. Just once in a while there may be some doubt about whether a loan will be repaid in full. This is one such case, but it is too early to speculate about it at this time. I really have nothing to add to that or to anything else I have already said.

SPEECH.PARA: What the honourable senator is asking me for is a suggestion that somehow in some mythical, hypothetical case EFIC will write into its rules that it will conduct incredibly painstaking searches to make sure that there is not some remote connection between a user of an EFIC finance facility and somebody called Gambino in the United States. I am sure that it will try to do that, but I cannot give guarantees about it, of course.

TALK.START.PARA: —This line of questioning arose in this instance because we had had assurances from Dr Fisher that the sort of thing that resulted in the $16m scam could not be repeated. He went on to eulogise and to say how wonderful things were and how efficient, competent and prudential they were. Then we find that we have another $8m at risk but, worse than that-this was not admitted, but must have been known about at the time-we found that it was not $8m but $16m, and only $8m is secured. If the Minister will not give me the assurance that our prudential arrangements are such that we are unlikely to do business with the likes of Mr Cantor again, I can only conclude that our prudential arrangements are less than satisfactory.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The $16m scam to which the honourable senator refers is totally unrelated to this. This is not a $16m scam. The honourable senator is not entitled to describe it as a scam at all at this stage. As far as the possibility of commercial risk in EFIC transactions is concerned compared with this possible $8m, sure, there are sums at commercial risk. Australian wheat farmers have sold $400m worth of wheat to one Saddam Hussein in the last couple of years. That money may be at risk. I do not hear Senator Bishop talking about that. I think she ought to look at that before the next Estimates hearings. That is a big risk.

—The Minister will recall that we did indeed deal with that matter in Estimates and we explored the fact that EFIC does not bear the risk for those resales; they are written into the national account and are not--
—No, you have got that wrong, too.
—Will the Minister enlighten us? Do tell me the difference.
—There is a lot of EFIC business with Middle East countries for the sale of wheat.

—Perhaps the Minister could tell me again the details and the way in which we use the national account, as distinct from EFIC, as insurance payments. That was why we had Appropriation Bill (No. 3), if I recall, was it not?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot give Senator Bishop the precise figures at the time; she has probably got them in the Hansard. The real distinction which I should perhaps make is that national interest money is government money, taxpayers' money; EFIC money is not. That is the point we have been trying to make for some time. It seems to have eluded Senator Bishop.

—The point did not elude me; I simply do not accept it. If it is in the public arena and is controlled by government, it is public money and, therefore, is accountable to this Parliament. The fact that the officers with whom the Minister is now dealing are paid for by public money and the fact that, in the final analysis, the Minister is accountable in this place means that we have to have proper and prudential arrangements. I am profoundly disappointed that the Minister finds that the loss of millions of dollars is something that can be simply smiled at and something about which it can be said, `Well, we are not doing too bad. Near enough is good enough. She'll be right, mate'.
—The Committee will now return to the Department of the Treasury.

—While the officers are coming into the chamber, Senator Walters has asked us to try to make sure that someone from the Australian Bureau of Statistics was here. We have endeavoured to do that and we have endeavoured with some success. In a moment, we will proceed to that matter before we get onto the outstanding matter from Senator Short. I gave a guarantee to Senator Walters that immediately after 8 o'clock we would try to deal with the outstanding matter of the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

—Mr Chairman, I ask for your indulgence. This Austrade matter was pushed back until 8 o'clock because of the difficulty with the attendance of witnesses. There is one question I would like to ask with regard to the Department of Finance. I too have a time constraint. Could I just ask one question of Finance and then leave the matter of the Australian Bureau of Statistics to Senator Walters?

—Senator Bishop can ask that. I really do not mind, if you do not mind, Mr Chairman, but the Department of Finance officers are not here at the moment; the Treasury officers are here. If I can answer the question, I will; if not, I will do what I can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question relates to a question that Senator Short began to ask when we were last dealing with Treasury. You, Mr Chairman, reminded Senator Short that we were in fact still dealing with Treasury and not the Department of Finance. Senator Short is unable to be here at the moment.
—I do not think I was here at that time.

—I beg your pardon; somebody else must have been in the chair. The question relates to the payment to Mr Burke. Both Senator Short and I asked questions at Estimates about the nature of the payment. Senator Short's question received an answer that the Department of Finance was not involved with the payment. I then asked: if it was decided that the payment was not a determination but was an act of grace payment, would the Department of Finance exercise its right to make that payment? Mr Barrett of the Department of Finance answered that he would be most reluctant in those circumstances to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had three separate answers from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) in this chamber. The first answer was that the power relied upon to make the lump sum payment was the general power conferred on the Minister by the Governor-General to make terms and conditions. On the following day, the Minister said that he relied on clause N of the terms and conditions. Then we were told that in fact he was relying on clause 2A(ii). Those three answers are inconsistent. At least two of them have to be wrong, if not three.

We were told finally that there was no way there could be a unilateral resignation. Anybody would know that. All that had to occur was that the resignation would be received. If that were done, my information is that the money would have been taxable at the highest marginal rate of 48.25 per cent but that if Mr Burke was terminated by an order of the Executive Council the sum would become an eligible termination payment and would be taxed at the rate of 31.25 per cent. In other words, the benefit to Mr Burke was not the $7,000 difference between the $28,000 and the $35,000 but, in fact, a further $3,000 which would be approximately the benefit of that taxation benefit.

Could two things be confirmed: firstly, could Treasury be most helpful and tell us whether the payment will be taxed at the lower rate-31.25 per cent-and, if not at that rate, whether it will be taxed at some other rate which is a lower rate? Secondly, could Treasury tell us whether this payment is finally to be construed as an act of grace payment, as I believe it ought properly to be? If so, it would therefore be taxed at the ordinary rate. Furthermore, it would have to be approved by the Minister of Finance (Mr Willis). Has the Department of Finance become involved in the deliberations of the need of the Minister to approve that payment? I add that it is not an approval that the Minister can delegate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop, perhaps you might help the chair by indicating under what reservation you are speaking at the moment.
—I am speaking to the questions that were not answered until the report was tabled, relating to the question of act of grace payments which were dealt with on 6 May, if my memory serves me.
—To the best of my knowledge, no approach has been made to the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) for an act of grace payment.

—Could the Parliamentary Secretary ascertain whether the Department of Finance has made inquiries about this payment-I think that he might find that it has-and whether the Auditor-General has been involved in this question? The Auditor-General has an interest in it too. Perhaps the Minister could come back to us with that information. Could he also confirm whether the payment will be taxed at the lower and favourable rate if it is construed as an eligible termination payment?

—I am not aware of any involvement by the Department of Finance. If there is some subsequent information I will supply it to Senator Bishop when it becomes available, but I do not intend to traverse the taxation affairs of any taxpayer.

—Could the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) ascertain for me whether there is a hypothetical person who was employed, who was to receive a commission from the Government and have it terminated by the Executive Council, as that would be construed as an eligible termination payment? I realise it might be an embarrassment but I would still like an answer.

—I am not the slightest bit embarrassed. I simply do not believe that it is appropriate to inquire about the taxation affairs of individuals. Every now and again Senator Bishop comes in here and poses a concern about privacy while it suits her. I intend to defend the privacy of taxpayers. I will not disclose their affairs and I will not pursue hypothetical rabbits down hypothetical burrows.
—I am disappointed to see that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer has joined the ranks of the defenders of Brian Burke, but so be it.
—Are there any further questions in relation to Finance? Perhaps we should go back to the Treasury and do things the proper way.

—Prior to the dinner break, Senator Short and I were asking questions regarding the Australian Bureau of Statistics and the error that was made with the double counting of the pay-roll tax in New South Wales. Could the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) explain, first of all, how that mistake was made; who made the decision two days before the election-which, as everybody would be well aware, was a very sensitive time to release these statistics-to release these statistics; and, when they were found to be incorrect in such a massive way, who decided what action should be taken to correct the announcement, especially at such a sensitive time? To my mind not nearly enough action was taken to rectify the situation. I want to know why further action was not been taken.
—Senator Walters, you might be able to help the Chair by indicating under what reservation you are speaking.
—We were asking these questions with the leave of the Committee.
—Obviously I was not in the Chair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —First Senator Short and then Senator Walters sought leave and, because of the generally cooperative way we were proceeding through Treasury estimates, I was happy to give it. I will deal with the last question for which I have a simpler answer and then I will work my way back through the others.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walters spoke about the response when the error was discovered. I will deal with that first. I think the Secretary of the New South Wales Treasury contacted the Australian Statistician during the afternoon and within an hour of that contact-I would not want to be precise, but approximately within an hour-a press release was issued by the Statistician and faxed to the New South Wales Treasury. The Treasury was immediately aware of, and able to take what action it chose with, that information, and publicly released in the usual way in mid-afternoon.

My understanding-and the best information I can give-is in two parts: firstly, the problem arises from a double counting of pay-roll tax paid by New South Wales Government authorities, and this should have been netted out from the figures as released. My further understanding is that this information was first released on 28 March and, prior to that, had been made available to the New South Wales Treasury which had raised a number of queries about those figures with the Statistician, but not this particular one. So those figures were released on 28 March.

What was released last week was a minor revision of those 28 March statistics and a disaggregation of the 28 March figures, rather than new information. There was no reason of which I am aware to challenge the accuracy of those figures because they had not been challenged when previously made available to the New South Wales Treasury. It is probably fair to say that there was somewhat more excitement about correcting it last week when the political significance of the statistics became available to the New South Wales Treasurer. He must have conducted a more rigorous review than he did in March.

I will now try to give the Committee some information about the timing of the release of the statistics, which is the other outstanding question. Senator Short gave some comparisons about the dates of release in other years and this year. Those figures that were released on 28 March, which are closely related to the relevant figures, were released at the same time in the previous year. The revised figures, or second phase release, was somewhat earlier but the timing was governed, as it should be, by the fact that they were released as soon as the figures became available.

While it was politically sensitive to release the information before the election, it would have been equally politically sensitive to have delayed releasing it until after the election. The Statistician's obligation is to release the information as soon as it becomes available and that is what took place. This information was, as I expected and anticipated, released by the Statistician as soon as it became available irrespective of the external circumstances because that is his obligation, and it was discharged on this occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —A few questions arise as a result of those answers. I will start with the last answer. Did the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) decide to put out a news release on its own and, if not, why not? Did it just report to Treasury and say, `We made a horrible mistake. We will leave it up to you to make the corrections'? Why did not the ABS decide to put out its own news release saying, `We have made a horrible mistake'?

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McMullan said that the news release occurred from midafternoon onwards. I heard the evening news but I heard no reference to it. I guess that that has nothing to do with anyone but the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. It was the station I was listening to. I certainly heard it on the 10.30 news that night. There was nothing on the news the next morning, which was Saturday, or on AM with regard to it. I was particularly concerned because I did take note that it was not on either of those sessions. I repeat: did the ABS decide to put out its own news release, follow it up and make sure that as many people as was possible in New South Wales were contacted on every channel to receive the news that it had made that extremely poor mistake at that time?

TALK.START.PARA: —It was an Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) news release. That is what was sent to the New South Wales Treasury.
—But they contacted Treasury and Treasury put it out.

—No. It was an ABS news release. One thing it did in distributing it was fax it to New South Wales. I did not see the news that night, but my advice is that Mr Greiner was displaying it in all its glory on television on the night in question.

—I will go back to the next morning and the early morning news. It certainly was not on the quarter to eight news. That was the program I was particularly monitoring, having heard it at 10.30 the previous night for the first time. It was also not on AM. It was not on those two programs, that is for sure. What efforts did the Australian Bureau of Statistics make, apart from just sending it around, to ensure that it did the best that was possible to cover for its error?

—The responsibility of the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) was to make the statement as quickly as possible and distribute it as comprehensively as it could. As far as I know, it was a normal release and got the same treatment as every other ABS news release and perhaps more. It was comprehensively covered on the television news in Sydney that night, although perhaps not as comprehensively as Senator Walters would have wished. I often find the same thing with stories. Television and radio stations never run the bits I want when I want them run. That is not matter over which the Bureau has any control, but it did assiduously endeavour to communicate the information to the people of New South Wales.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —What Senator McMullan said was what I feared-that it took its normal course along with other news releases. I know that if he really tries, as I have on odd occasions, he can do a lot better than that.
—Sometimes you really try and nothing happens.

—For Senator McMullan's information, I tell him that he can ring the AM program and the early morning news and appeal. I am sure that the appeal by the Australian Bureau of Statistics that a very important mistake had been made on the day of an election would have been heeded.
—The day before.

—The mistake was made the day before, but the day of the election was a Saturday, which had the quarter to eight news program in the morning. The AM program now occurs on Saturday morning. Senator McMullan could have made sure, had the Australian Bureau of Statistics made that extra overture, that it would have been run. I do not think that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation would be so biased as to refuse to run it. That obviously was not done.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of questions, Senator McMullan said that, on the first release on 28 March, certain statistics were given to the New South Wales Treasury and that there were some queries from Treasury on the first phase of the release. Were any corrections made as a result of the Treasury's queries on that issue?

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, the queries did not relate to these taxation questions. But, yes, I understand some corrections were made.

—That is of great concern to me because if the Australian Bureau of Statistics had already made a number of mistakes on 28 March and the New South Wales Treasury, through queries, pointed out mistakes and the ABS had corrected these mistakes, when the second phase occurred surely to heaven people would have gone over the statistics that were about to be released two days before an election with a fine tooth comb. I would have thought that, as a result of the first lot of mistakes, the ABS would have been doubly sure, particularly when it was going to release them at such a very sensitive time, and that it would have gone over those figures so thoroughly that a mistake could not possibly have been made. With all the best will in the world, once that mistake saying that New South Wales was the highest taxed State was released and campaigned on so heavily for two full days, it would be very difficult to undo. I find it extraordinary that the New South Wales Treasury was the one, again through queries, which had to bring to the attention of the ABS that it had made yet a further mistake.
—Before Senator McMullan responds, I remind Senator Walters that she is pursuing this matter by leave and that time is ticking on.
—I have not taken long, and that is my last question. I am just relying on the answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters has profoundly misunderstood the significance of those 28 March figures and my comments about the corrections. Firstly, my understanding is that the process of sending material to the relevant State treasuries-not just New South Wales-prior to the release of information and then having a discussion about the way it is presented, the nature of the material and making corrections and modifications on the basis of information from State treasuries, is normal and had happened with regard to all the States, not just New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: The significance of what I said about 28 March is that the New South Wales Treasury had the information about the tax statistics, which were so controversial in the middle of May, prior to 28 March and made no queries about them. It did not say it did not think those figures were right. It raised no questions about them. The figures that were released in May were figures that had already been checked and not queried by the New South Wales Treasury. That is the significance of my point about 28 March.

That does not excuse anybody making an error and nobody would seek to do that. It does say that the normal processes by which the possibility of error might be checked were undertaken and that those errors had not been detected by, amongst others, the New South Wales Treasury. That does not pass the blame for the error to the Treasury of New South Wales; the blame still lies with the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) and it accepts that. Senator Walters has to accept that that is the significance of the 28 March release, not that there is some deficiency in the ABS such that New South Wales has to keep pointing things out to it. This is part of the normal interchange of information.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that previously I said it was the last question but just for clarification could Senator McMullan also give me an answer to this question: if the New South Wales Treasury had the taxation figures from 28 March, why were they not released at the normal time? Why was there the delay if it was known as early as 28 March?

—The first phase was released on 28 March. There was a second process of disaggregation of the data, which happens every year. When that was concluded in May, the figures were released. That second process happens every year.

—Before I proceed, I have to say that, as Chairman of Committees, I regret that leave was given to bring forward matters which were not in the reservations or the reports. We have a set procedure which allows the proceedings of the Appropriations to proceed. We brought that in so that the process could become much more efficient. If we bring matters in by leave, we make a mockery of that new process. If I am in the chair in the future and leave is requested to bring in extraneous matters which are not in the reports or the reservations to the reports, I will refuse leave.
—Can I comment on what you have just said?

—You can, Senator Walters, but I am outlining to you and to all honourable senators that we adopted some new procedures so that Estimates would be run more efficiently at the committee stage. If matters are mentioned in the report for further examination, they can be further examined. If they are mentioned in reservations to those reports, they too can be further examined. We cannot stray from that; otherwise, logically we will be going back to examining all matters pertaining to every department. As Chairman of Committees, I have a responsibility to uphold the Standing Orders that we have now. I will do that and, as a senator, I can refuse leave. Only one person has to refuse leave and I will do that from the chair if necessary. Does Senator Walters wish to comment?

—Very briefly. We were given leave this afternoon because an extraordinary circumstance occurred after the Estimates. If we are to be denied flexibility on any matter that we might consider to be of a major nature, in our committee reports we will have to move to far broader reservations than are necessary through not being able to ask questions. This can be covered, of course, by our saying, `Or anything else that occurs in the interim between the sittings of Estimates committees and consideration by the Committee of the Whole'. It would be a shame if we resorted to that. We were given leave only because this matter arose after Estimates. It was of a serious nature and we felt we had a right to ask a few questions. That is why the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) gave us leave.

—I have outlined what my response will be in the future. It is my responsibility to uphold the Standing Orders and I will do so. The fact that something came up after Estimates and is not in the Estimates does not allow somebody to raise it at the committee stage of the Estimates. Senator Walters, if you wish to make your reservations broad, I suppose you can do so. But you should realise now that I have ruled some reservations out of order because they were too broad. Are there any further questions in relation to the Department of the Treasury?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to talk very briefly about the Australian Taxation Office. Given the generous attitude during the Senate Estimates hearings, I do not intend to use this Appropriations debate to pursue certain outstanding matters. However, I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer whether it would be possible to have a response to a matter that I raised in a discussion of matters of public interest which concerned some guidelines arising from the Moorby case.

SPEECH.PARA: I take this opportunity of thanking the Parliamentary Secretary, Senator McMullan, and all those officers from the Australian Taxation Office who appeared before the Committee and also others who provided the written answers. I remind the Committee that many observers, including practitioners and others, believe that the Senate Estimates process involving the Australian Taxation Office is now compulsory reading. I think the openness of the approach has again restored to the Parliament an information source that is very necessary in our Westminster system-a source that, regrettably, was neglected by the Parliament, with the vacuum being filled by certain outside groups with access to the Australian Taxation Office. I am pleased that this mandate to the Parliament has been restored.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I respond to Senator Watson, I will respond to Senator Short who asked a question before the consideration of the Committee was suspended for dinner. I did not have an opportunity to answer it before the suspension. He was concerned about the lack of detail provided on the modernisation project in the recent Budget Papers. There was a fair amount of detail in the 1989-90 Budget Statements. In view of the time, I will not talk about that at length; but I am advised that the long term project is proceeding largely to plan and, therefore, we felt it was not necessary to include further details in the most recent Budget Papers. Given that Senator Short has raised this matter and that a lot of taxpayers' money is involved, the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of Finance will examine the possibility of including more details about the project in forthcoming Statement No. 3 for the 1991-92 Budget. That should answer the question which was asked when Senator Vanstone was in the chair prior to dinner.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank Senator Watson for his general remarks. I am not sure that I have more to add to the Moorby case than that which has been provided. If there is something in particular, I may be able to do so. Otherwise, if the honourable senator wants to contact me subsequently, I will provide more information.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That the report of Estimates Committee B be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —We shall start consideration of Estimates Committee B with the Department of Defence.
—I wish to raise some matters contained in the reservations in my name. Is it appropriate to do that at this stage?
—Yes, Senator.
—Will there be no debate in relation to the adoption of the Estimates for that Department?

—Senator Durack, as I understand it, that is the motion before the Committee at the moment, and under that motion you can consider reservations made by you or, for that matter, any others in the report.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator DURACK

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise with the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) the question of the future of the North West Cape communications station. The Minister will recall that at the Estimates Committee B hearings on 16 April I raised this question and was told that negotiations with the United States of America in relation to the takeover of the station by Australia had not progressed very far up to that period, despite the fact that it was a year after the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had announced that Australia would be taking it over. I was told that there would be a seven-year transition or phase-in period for Australia to take over control of the facility from the United States.

INTERJECT.PARA: I was also interested to know whether at the end of that period, when the takeover is completed, there will be any United States presence there. I had a very firm answer of no from Major-General Grey to that question; in other words, that there would not be an entire withdrawal by the United States. It was with some considerable surprise that less than a fortnight later it was reported that the American commander of the base had informed United States personnel on the base-there are 400 of them-that they would all be withdrawn by October 1993. I understand from the answers to some questions in another place, I think it was, that that has been confirmed. In any event, it has been confirmed by other means that the United States now does intend to withdraw its 400 personnel by October 1993.

Within a fortnight of the answers given to me at the Estimates Committee hearing in April-assuming that those answers were accurate at the time-there was a very sudden change in the situation concerning this important matter. I would like the Minister to bring us up to date as to the exact position and why the decision to withdraw the American personnel by October 1993 was apparently not known by him or by the officers present at the time of the Estimates hearing. Perhaps of more importance is the exact situation on the base as from October 1993 when the American personnel are withdrawn. I ask: how many Australian personnel will be required to operate the base as from that date? Will we have sufficiently trained personnel to do so within two years, or will some American presence remain thereafter, and for how long? Obviously, from the information we now have, the Americans do intend to withdraw entirely from that base.

The other question which is of vital importance relates to the cost to Australia of the takeover of the facility. It was said that there would be negotiations about these cost arrangements, and that was to be an ongoing process of bargaining and so forth, but in view of the fact that the withdrawal is now to occur within two years instead of within seven years, I would expect that there would be something more definite about the cost of this transfer. At what stage will the Australian payments be required to commence?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers given in the Estimates Committee were accurate. What has substantially come out is the United States Navy's view of its timetable. At the moment it is not a United States Government view. Therein lies the difference between the answers given at the Estimates Committee and the information that Senator Durack has alluded to today. What I said in the Estimates Committee still holds.

SPEECH.PARA: The major negotiations surrounding the timetable will occur at the next Ausmin talks, which are likely to be in October this year in Australia. If in fact the US Government adopts the Navy's view and decides to pull all of its officers and ranks out of the base in October 1993 instead of over the seven-year period outlined after talks between Secretary Cheney and me, we would have to look at that timetable again. I have not yet had any official communication from the Secretary of Defence to this effect yet. We will certainly be discussing the matter at that time. Senator Durack has asked whether, if this does occur, we will be in a position to fill the void, if you like. That void would be sought to be filled not only by Royal Australian Navy personnel but also by civilian contractors. Senator Durack also raised the cost of the facility. I repeat what I said at the Estimates Committee, that that will be subject to negotiation on a government to government basis.

I can only presume that the reason for the US Navy putting forward its view so publicly at the moment, from last October until now, is the enormous pressures the US Navy is under to make cost savings. The United States Defence Force is facing a very major cut in expenditure over the next three years of at least 12 per cent in real terms from its previous high. I suppose it is its responsibility to put forward as many cost savings proposals as possible, and according to its preferred timetable. But I repeat: at the moment that is not an official view from the United States Government, and I would expect that this and other matters will feature in those discussions at the Ausmin talks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We seem to be faced with a rather extraordinary situation where the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) is saying that the statement which had been made by the commander to the personnel at the base is that, to use the Minister's words, the United States Navy intends to withdraw the 400 personnel by October 1993. At the Estimates Committee hearing, Dr Dibb said:

SPEECH.PARA: I will be going to the United States next month to follow on from the negotiations that Senator Ray had there last year.

That month has now practically past and, presumably, Dr Dibb has been to the United States. But in light of this bombshell, as one might describe it-certainly it has been a bombshell to the people of Exmouth-I would have thought that the official view of the United States Government would have been known by now. I would have thought that Dr Dibb, having been there, would have found that out or the Minister would have found it out by communicating directly with the United States Government.

We seem to have an extraordinary situation where a distinction is being drawn between the decision of the Navy to withdraw and the decision of the United States Government, which may not be in favour of withdrawal in two years time. Is the Minister saying that this whole matter is going to remain in limbo until the Ausmin talks, which I gather are scheduled for November this year? By then, the situation may be that there will not be a withdrawal by October 1993. If that is the case, is there some other date which is less than seven years hence or are we left with complete uncertainty over the next few months as to whether there is going to be this withdrawal by October 1993?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —These matters do not come up in a vacuum. I am sure there will be preliminary discussions prior to the Ausmin talks, as there is on every issue, to establish some initial positions. As I indicated before, that is the appropriate time at which we intend to take up this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Durack asked about Dr Dibb's visit to the United States. That indeed did occur but, regrettably, my briefing from him on the results of this trip is tomorrow morning and was not this morning; otherwise, I could expand a bit more on what he may have discussed in this regard. But whether it was proper and right for the US Navy to make its position known in the way that it has is a matter that will probably be discussed in October.

The position at both the last Ausmin talks and the bilateral talks I had with the Secretary of Defense, Mr Cheney, was that a seven-year timetable appeared to be the most appropriate. Therefore, there was ample time to discuss things such as: the cost of the facility; a phased-in Australian command of the base; and a phased withdrawal of US personnel. I have not had any communication from Secretary Cheney that changes any of that. Therefore, I assert that is still the United States Government position.

These issues will be discussed in detail in October-not November as Senator Durack referred to-and we will be making a statement afterwards.
