We have also given a commitment, once the position becomes clear, to brief our civilian work force-the whole township is very much dependant on the base-as to how we see its future in terms of how many personnel we will require and what other developments may occur there. We have committed ourselves to that process and we will keep our commitment.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the question raised by Senator Durack of the very low frequency station, is the Defence Science and Technology Organisation actively pursuing alternative technologies in view of the fact that the actual transmission system of the VLF station is a very old technology? Alternative means of communicating with submarines are potentially available. Do we have to maintain that structure in 20 years time, for example?

—As Senator MacGibbon would know, it is valve technology, which is quite old, but it was also a quite staggering development at the time. We are looking towards upgrading the equipment. Whether there are sufficient alternative systems available, their expense would be enormous at this stage. I do recall-I have not had advice on this-that the United States has been trying to develop alternative technologies. I am not sure where it is at with that. I know it will be very expensive. We will be looking at upgrading it to keep it going for a number of years to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to two issues, one relating to an unanswered question as at the date of the Committee's preparation of the report and the second relating to an issue on which I have filed a reservation. I refer to the question that was taken on notice at the Estimates Committee hearings with regard to the construction of housing by the Defence Housing Authority, generally known as the Sheppard contract, at the Royal Australian Air Force Base Tindal and to the response that was provided to me on 7 May. The response reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The contract sum for the project is $3.088 million; variations totalling $36,495 have so far been approved for items that would normally arise in a project of this nature. Negotiations are continuing on other variations claimed by the builder.

I draw to the attention of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) that I consider that to be a very inadequate answer, given the nature of normal contract administration. Surely, the answer should have indicated what variations in the nature and cost of estimated works there were on this particular contract. Given the nature of my question on notice, I would have thought that a more comprehensive answer could have been provided, detailing the degree, significant or otherwise, of the variations anticipated, and even some cost estimates of the likely nature of additional costs-particularly as the question was taken on notice and some weeks elapsed for the answer to be provided. I wonder whether the Minister is now in a position to provide the additional information with regard to that particular contract that I believe ought to have been provided to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I point out that it is not always possible to get every answer in by the time the report is prepared, but every question is at least attempted to be answered by the Department. There are no outstanding questions, although one question was refused to be answered. If there is an implied criticism of the Department of Defence by Senator Tambling, I reject it.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the answer to his question is simply here in the question he asked. But to suggest that, whilst we have got negotiations on with the builder, we should make public our costs and our estimates would completely undermine our negotiating position. It is a ridiculous assertion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point I make is that the question was taken on notice on 16 April. The answer that is printed was given to me on 7 May. I am not looking for information that would indicate the degree of commercial dealing that I understand, naturally, has to go on, but I am asking whether or not the variations under negotiation are significant. If they are significant, what is the nature and the cost of the anticipated blow-out of the particular area? I do not want the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) necessarily to give me a dollars and cents figure, but I would like to know whether the variation could be in the order of 10 per cent, 20 per cent, 30 per cent, 60 per cent or 100 per cent of the initial contract price.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw to the Minister's attention the fact that at the Senate Estimates Committee last year I raised a whole series of questions with regard to the very unusual nature of the tender process and to the successful tenderer, a company by the name of Shepherd, which was brought in for the conduct of this project under very unusual and abnormal arrangements that were set in place against other tenderers within the Northern Territory. I referred to the fact that a successful tenderer, who had formerly carried out work for the Defence Housing Authority in South Australia, was picked up and transposed into this project. It created quite a degree of controversy at the time and I am, therefore, keen to establish to what extent the cost blow-outs on this contract will vary from the original cost estimate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an appropriate question for the next Estimates committee on Defence. I would have thought the negotiations would be finalised by then and Senator Tambling could get the figures then. It is not possible for me tonight to establish what the variations were. All I can say is that the figure of $36,495 has been approved so far, and negotiations continue on the other amounts. It is appropriate that Senator Tambling ask those questions at the next Estimates Committee hearings in the spring, and get the figures then. I am not in a position tonight to say whether, in my opinion, significant or insignificant amounts remain to be negotiated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It concerns me that the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) is not prepared to pick up the concerns that have been expressed. Given that today is 28 May and the answer that was given was provided on 7 May, there has been a further three-week period since the date of the tabling of the response that we currently have access to. I had hoped that the Minister would be able to say tonight whether the petty cash item of $36,000-which I accept as being quite routine and standard-would in any way have been varied. To leave this matter until the contract would be well and truly concluded-the time of the October Estimates Committee hearings, when we will again have an opportunity to review it in fine detail-could well give us major concern.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Senate is well aware, the construction of Defence housing at the Royal Australian Air Force base at Tindal by the predecessor to the Defence Housing Authority-the Australian Construction Services-has been fraught with very considerable difficulty. In fact, the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, has outlined that 17 cases of fraud were under investigation within his own Department. Of course, that did not cover any of the investigations for fraud that were also under way in the Department of Defence, the client department.

The Defence Housing Authority has taken over the role of providing housing. This is a new contract. It is one about which I am keen to ensure that there is no continuation of accusations of fraud against the Department of Defence as the client department or in the Katherine contracting community. I would have thought that the Minister would appreciate the serious nature of this, and would not have seen fit to sideflick it until we get the opportunity to look at it in a more audited way next October, when the contract will be well and truly concluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tambling says that I am not taking him seriously. On his track record, sometimes I do and sometimes I do not. His point is probably fair when he says that to wait until October when the additional information becomes available is too long to wait. I accept that point and, therefore, will give him a response when the negotiations are finished, and the moment we are notified that there are further variations I will let him know about that. I do not have a time line on that. I imagine that it will not be too long before these negotiations are concluded and I will then send him the figures rather than wait until October.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) for that response. The second issue that I wish to refer to this evening with regard to Defence matters is that on which I filed a reservation as, in fact, I have done across a number of departments on issues that relate to the coastal surveillance function and apprehension and surveillance across northern waters.

SPEECH.PARA: There was a series of questions in this area taken on notice in advance of the Estimates Committee hearings and asked at the time. I notice that the Department of Defence on this occasion has chosen not to provide discrete financial estimates with regard to the operation of either Navy or Royal Australian Air Force facilities that have been applied to this important function that closely follows the work of illegal fishermen in north Australian waters.

In the previous financial year I think we ascertained that figures well in excess of $20m in the Department of Defence estimates were allocated to this function. I am not implying in any way that those estimates are for work that ought not to be carried out-in fact, it should be so. However, the need for very close work between, I think, eight or nine Commonwealth Government departments that are involved in these important functions, shows that the Department of Defence has to take a very prominent role because of the issues that have been raised.

I note that in recent weeks there has been a change and that the Coastwatch organisation has taken over a much larger part of the surveillance burden. This will, of course, require adjustments in the various Budget estimates of the Department of Defence. I had hoped that the Department would be in a position to give us estimates of just how these changes will impact on the Department compared with those that are now more properly being carried out by the Coastwatch organisation. I am aware that a number of my colleagues would probably contend that other government departments may not be the appropriate bodies for the air surveillance that is necessary.

There have been a number of comments in this regard by many people across the community. While I have certainly challenged the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Evans, to take a far greater leadership role in negotiating particular arrangements with the Indonesian authorities, particularly in relation to the apprehension of illegal fishermen, it is certainly an issue that has to be pursued.

I note comments made by the Chief of Air Staff, Air Marshall Ray Funnell, in the Australian of 20 March this year. Air Marshall Funnell said that control of the air-sea gap was an objective. He went on to say:

It is certainly not a reality. We do not even know what is going on there, let alone being capable of controlling it. Until we do know what is going on in there, we are always going to be in a position of disadvantage.

In this context it is particularly worrying to note that there appears to be an increase in attempts to make illegal landings across Australian territory. We are well aware from the statistics that there have been increases in the number of fishing vessels apprehended in Australia territorial waters.

Of course, while we have concentrated our efforts on illegal fishing, we must never walk away from the responsibilities that these other functions also have with regard to drug smuggling and drug activities across northern Australia. There has to be very close cooperation not only with the Indonesian authorities on matters such as illegal fishing, but also with Papua New Guinea, particularly in relation to drug activities.

Until such time as the coordination activities between the various departments, including the Department of Defence, really do streamline our northern and coastal surveillance regime, there will be extremely difficult periods for us to address. I hope that in the Budget estimates that we will be able to look at in October, the Department will not seek to hide behind the cost analysis of these important functions and will, in fact, make available to the Senate a full breakdown of all costs related to this activity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The department is not trying to hide behind cost estimates. We do not meet every demand from the Opposition for a cost analysis when it does not fit the way we set out our Budget. We have tried as much as possible here to give the costs of a patrol boat at sea and also the Orion costs per hour-that is, the full cost-and how much we are subsidised for that.

SPEECH.PARA: The general question that Senator Tambling has raised does cross a number of portfolios, but the parent body of Coastwatch, of course, is the Australian Customs Service. If he has major policy areas to raise there, I suggest that he raise them under those estimates. Other than that, what Senator Tambling said was more of an editorial, which may or may not have merit, but there is nothing to be answered specifically.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the Government's announcement of the purchase of a glass reinforced plastic section of Carrington Slipways Pty Ltd as a result of Carrington's having gone into receivership. From the Government's announcement, I understand that it bought this section of Carrington's operations because of its importance to the inshore mine hunter pro- ject. I raise the following questions: what has the Government in fact bought? Is it part of the slipway, property, equipment, or simply the right to use the property? What is the relationship that this has with Carrington Slipways? I understand that construction will not be proceeding with the rushcutter class mine hunter, with the plastic hull, until probably some time in 1992. What does the Government propose to do to keep that facility available for that construction when it is required?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following a company offer, the Department purchased the equity of Carrington Slipways Pty Ltd in the mine hunter construction facility in October 1990. The facility is now known as the Department of Defence Shipbuilding Facility, Tomago. A licence agreement enabled the CSPL to operate the facility under Commonwealth ownership. In December 1990, Carrington Slipways Pty Ltd was foreclosed, and Messrs G. Hall and G. Kelly of Price Waterhouse were appointed as agents for the Commonwealth Bank of Australia as mortgagee in possession of all assets of CSPL. The agents advise that the obligations of the licence agreement under which Carrington operated the facility would not be met and the licence was subsequently terminated in January 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: Representatives of several Australian companies attended an industry briefing held at the construction facility on 11 February 1991. As a result, an agreement was signed on 22 February 1991 with R and H Transport Pty Ltd for storage of inert carbon anodes in a non-construction area of the facility. If a suitable operator is not found for the construction area, the facility will be mothballed pending a decision on further mine hunter inshore construction. An announcement therein will be made on Thursday as to the future of the mine hunter program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do we presume from that that we will build more mine hunters?
—The honourable senator can make whatever presumption he likes. I will be making my announcement on Thursday, not tonight, if possible.

—I presume that since the Minister is a responsible Minister and a careful custodian of public funds, he would not have bought the facility unless he intended to produce further ships. If that is not the intention, would he tell the Senate what was the intention when the plant was purchased?
—He changed his mind!

—I thank the Shadow Minister for Defence, Science and Personnel (Senator Newman). I think the second part of the honourable senator's assumption about me is correct. However, I will let others judge the first part. I repeat: these issues have been subject to the Force Structure Review. Decisions have been made as to the future of Australia's involvement in mine hunters. Again, I am paying a price to some extent for trying to go to Parliament first when several of these--
—First?
—That is right. I do not think I will ever do it again.
—You came to Parliament first?
—That is right. I do not think I will ever do that again, because too much of the decisions have leaked out.
—What about the union movement?

—That is quite proper in advance, but not in this matter. We are now diverting onto other matters. A whole range of people will be briefed before the statement, including the union movement, the Returned Services League, Arthur--
—Parliament is last?
—What I think I will do next time we get a Cabinet decision is just go out and announce it. I will not bother about Parliament. Then honourable senators opposite would all be complaining.
—You virtually have.

—That may or may not be true. I am just a victim of trying to do the right thing, I believe. To return to Senator MacGibbon's point, I will be making reference to that in the statement and the supporting documents will also make reference to the future of the mine hunter project.

—In view of the fact that the program started in 1975, and that the Defence committee, having been given a request by the Minister of the day to inquire into it two years ago, reported very adversely that the program was a failure, we find it very surprising that the purchase of this facility was undertaken when presumably, on all the evidence, it had no purpose as a producing base, as a shipyard, for the Defence Department.

—Well, I would not agree with the statement that the facility is of use only to the Australian Defence Department. Again, I cannot detail that much more, and probably will not even do so on Thursday. There are other parties interested in taking it over. I will not prejudice their claims in this matter, but I do challenge the fact that only the Defence Department could use this facility.
—Will this be announced as part of the statement as to what will happen to this facility, as well as what will happen to the mine hunter project?
—No, some of those matters are out of my hands because other commercial interests are exploring particular options at the moment. I cannot say that they will be concluded by Thursday.

—By way of concluding the exchange I just had with the Minister, is he suggesting in his claim that he is coming to the Parliament first that foreign defence attaches, as well as the union movement, have not been briefed before the Parliament?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am not claiming that at all. In many of these things, on an embargoed basis, it is usual to brief people beforehand. On this occasion, we are making sure that various interested parties are briefed beforehand. As I said before, that will include the RSL and some of the union movement involved. I must say that my previous experience is that they are the last ones to break an embargo on these matters. A variety of others will be pre-briefed on this particular subject. However, I did desire as much as possible, having gone through the Cabinet process, to put down a statement in Parliament rather than just as a press release or holding a press conference on it.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact has to be recognised, as I now recognise, that so many people in the end-and I am talking about within the Defence Department-must have the issues run past them. A press release could not be issued in some of these matters without some of it leaking at times. I have often said that Defence leaks on some of these matters but does not leak on security matters, so at least we have it the right way around. However, I would prefer that no departments leaked, but they do. As such, I can understand some angst that a variety of press reports-many of which are inaccurate, by the way, but some of which are accurate-preview it before it is seen in Parliament.

There are a couple of lessons to be learnt from that-either have the press statement straight away or time the Cabinet decision and the statement in Parliament for the same day. I am not sure that that is always workable because we have to print documents. I give this example of why there is a delay in Cabinet making a statement to Parliament. I want to make available to this Parliament the force structure review; the interdepartmental committee report on Wrigley; the corporate communications plan; probably an executive summary of the two previous reviews; and, by the time we overcome some printing difficulties, some of the documents on the Ready Reserve. I will try to put all of those out at the one time and have all of them printed. I also intend to have a publication printed to give to servicemen so that they know about the proposals, and that will take a week or so.

But I accept criticism that too many aspects of this have leaked out. I do not know of any Minister at any time who has been able to track down and stop leaks absolutely. I recall that at one stage the Opposition's whole Budget was leaked and we never found the perpetrator of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not in Government at the time. It was not my Budget.

—This is the difference between Senator Newman and me. I take collective responsibility for 100 years of the Australian Labor Party. People on the other side have amnesia-anything prior to 1983 does not exist; including the mine hunter program which went on for 7 1/2 years under the Opposition's stewardship. That is the point I make. I do not ask the honourable senator to accept it, but my intention was to try to follow the proper procedures and go to Cabinet and then to Parliament to make those announcements.

SPEECH.PARA: Some areas have been briefed. Virtually every sitting member of parliament whose electorate is affected will be briefed on Thursday morning on an embargoed basis. I will also try to make the documents available to the Opposition, not under the two-hour rule, but 3 1/2 hours beforehand-all in an attempt to try to promote a constructive debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that explanation, but it still raises questions. If, as he said, the Parliament is to be the first to know, I question why any of these briefings should take place before the Parliament is informed. Why is it that the Defence Force personnel, who are surely the people most intimately involved in any major changes to the Defence Force, are the last to be informed-after the union movement, after foreign defence attaches, after the Returned Services League, and after people who have some defence base or other facility in their electorate? I think that seems a very strange order of priorities.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to spend the time of the Senate labouring the point any more, but I ask: which members of the union movement have been briefed? I understand that that occurred last week. There will be quite a long time-lag in this whole briefing exercise. It does not seem to me that the Minister is coming to the Parliament first. I understand that the union leadership was briefed on about 22 May. Why was it briefed so early? Who was briefed and what was the justification for this briefing?

TALK.START.PARA: —The union movement was briefed then because that was the day upon which I was available to do it; I was not available on other days. I think the people briefed were members of the Defence Industry Committee-that is, people from those unions which are directly involved. I do not have the names here, but I can provide them because they are the representatives on that Committee. The two things do not follow in one sense. If there have been leaks about it I am sure that they have not come from the union movement.
—I am not asking where the leaks came from. I am asking about priorities.
—It was convenient to brief them on that particular day. It is convenient to brief the others this week.
—Why any of them before the Parliament?

—It is a normal tradition that you give some briefing to those people who are directly concerned. It is just not possible to brief the whole Defence Force beforehand. I think we have made it fairly clear that every change comes in from day one. As I have indicated in the Estimates Committee hearings if not elsewhere, this statement has an implementation plan which will go for more than nine years. There will not be a revolution on day one. It will be a process of evolutionary change which can be managed and which will protect the interests of those in the armed forces. That is an absolute prerequisite of a force structure review.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not find that answer acceptable in any shape or form. The Minister is a member of the Executive of this country and he is responsible to the Parliament-that is where his responsibility lies. His first job is to come here and inform the Parliament of what he is doing on such a major issue. The people who have subsidiary interests are special interest groups and they will have a great interest in what the Government has decided. But the proper role of a Minister is to come to the Parliament and announce these things. He should not be selectively briefing journalists or Ministers weeks ahead. We do not need to look for leaks--
—Are you saying I briefed journalists?

—I am suggesting that the Minister has briefed journalists and I am suggesting that his colleague has briefed journalists. It has been going on for some weeks. I wish to move to other matters because we will not get anywhere by persisting with this one.
—Let me answer that one first.

—I have limited time and I would like to finish tonight if I can. I would like to raise a few matters relating to questions that were taken on notice and I would like to follow up some answers. Reference to page 2901 of the Senate Hansard shows clearly that it was a warning that Senator Macdonald received. He was not named. There is a gulf of difference between the two terms.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, upon notice, on 12 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: What are the numbers of CES clients currently registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service and classed as Unemployed Awaiting Placement:
(a) by each office of the Commonwealth Employment Service;

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth Employment Service collects data on numbers of unemployed awaiting placement at local CES office level (local UAP) for internal management purposes only. The data is not released because it is neither an accurate measure of unemployment nor a reliable indicator of changes in unemployment. General release of UAP data would involve an undue use of Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) resources in preparation of material and responses to inquiries, yet it would provide no additional reliable information on the labour market.

The UAP data is based on records of registrations held in CES Offices. While the CES removes individuals from the register when it becomes aware that they are no longer seeking work (e.g., they have found work or they have left the labour force), registrants are not required to inform the CES when this is the case. (Unemployment beneficiaries are, of course, required to inform the Department of Social Security). To seek to ensure that all individuals are removed from the register as soon as they find a job would require an undue and unjustified diversion of CES resources to this task. Further not all people seeking employment register with the CES.

In short, the UAP data essentially provides a measure of the number of people who have registered with the CES and are still listed as possibly requiring assistance, but unavoidably it includes many who no longer require this assistance. It is certainly not a measure of the level of unemployment.
The inaccuracies and distortions in the data are especially significant at the local level.

The most accurate indicator of the number of people in Australia actually seeking employment is available from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) estimates, collected via the monthly Labour Force Survey, which are specifically and rigorously designed to measure unemployment in accordance with International Labour Organisation standards. These ABS figures, which are the official measure of unemployment in Australia, are available monthly for 60 regions in Australia.

DEET also prepares annually a document titled ``Developments in Regional Labour Markets-Australia''. This provides estimates, based in part on regional data from the ABS Labour Force Survey, of unemployment levels and unemployment rates in Local Government Areas. While I would stress that the figures in this publication are only estimates and not the actual situation, they do provide the best available estimates of unemployment at a local level. The next update of the document covering the June quarter 1990 is currently in preparation. DEET is also taking steps to ensure greater timeliness in the production of these estimates in the future.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 10 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was there an evacuation at the Lucas Heights Nuclear Facility in early March 1991.
(2) Was the evacuation caused by the failure of the ventilation to Building 54, sometimes known as the ``hot box''.
(3) Was the building evacuated until the fault was repaired, and how long did this take.
(4) Was any notification of the incident given to the local council; if not, why not.
(5) Was any radioactivity released as a result of the incident, or was there a risk of release.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) One building, Building 54, was evacuated for about four hours on 21 February 1991.

(2) The evacuation was in line with standard procedures for buildings in which chemicals or radioactive materials are handled, following a malfunction in the electrical power supply to the building and, consequently, the ventilation system. Building 54 contains handling cells for the remote manipulation of radioactive materials used in the production of medical radioisotopes. Such cells are known in the nuclear industry as ``hot cells''. The term ``hot box'' is unknown.
(3) Yes. Ventilation to the handling cells was restored within 15 minutes. Electrical power to the rest of the building ventilation system took a further three hours to restore.
(4) No. The event was an operational inconvenience only and had no health or safety significance.
(5) Air sampling within the building showed there was no significant release of radioactivity.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 10 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the announcement made by the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Brown) on 4 March 1991 regarding plans to accelerate construction and maintenance of the Bruce Highway over the next five years:

(1) How many kilometres long are each of the planned four lane sections to be completed on the southern approaches to Mackay, Townsville and Cairns, and precisely where will each of these sections be located.

(2) (a) How many kilometres long is the planned four lane section to be completed on the northern approach to Townsville, and precisely where will this section be located; and (b) how much money will be spent on a flood-free crossing at the Bohle River.

(3) Which of the contradictory statements in the Minister's press release on 4 March is correct, namely, that the upgrading to the southern approach to Townsville will be completed or that it is under consideration.

(4) Is the upgrading to Townsville's southern approach, described as being under consideration, a different project from the new four lane section also promised as a detailed objective in the 4 March announcement.
(5) What is the nature of the upgrading under consideration, how much will it cost, when would work commence and conclude, and precisely where would it be situated.

(6) (a) How many kilometres of the Bruce Highway between Ayr and Townsville does the Government expect will be resurfaced through both the $400 million program and the disaster relief program; and (b) what sections will be resurfaced and when.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Land Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Federal Government fully funds and maintains the National Highway system. It determines priorities and objectives for individual corridors in accordance with its five year rolling National Highway strategy. The Minister for Land Transport's statement of 4 March 1991 detailed the Federal strategy for the next five years for the Bruce Highway (Brisbane to Cairns) which forms part of the National Highway in Queensland.

State road authorities act as design and construction agents on behalf of the Commonwealth. They are responsible for developing specific details of projects consistent with the Federal strategy, which are submitted to the Minister for Land Transport for his approval.

(1) In relation to the future upgrading of the southern approaches to Mackay, the Queensland Department of Transport has submitted a number of projects for the Minister's consideration. These are pavement overlay from Sandy Creek to Bakers Creek (about 7km) and duplication of the highway from Bakers Creek to Boundary Road (about 2.5kms).

Proposed works for the southern approaches to Townsville include the widening of University Road from the Flinders Highway to University Creek. Consideration of these projects by the Federal Minister is contingent upon finalisation by the Queensland Department of Transport of a review of major roads in Townsville and the need for the declaration of University Road as part of the National Highway system.
Projects on a stretch of about 10 kilometres of National Highway on the southern approaches to Cairns are under consideration.

These include a number of sections of the Bruce Highway, namely Skeleton Creek to Roberts Road (estimated $4.1 million), Robert Road to Mackey Creek with particular attention given to Maitland Road to Mackey Creek section (estimated $1.6 million).

The Robert Road to Maitland section will take in the town of Edmonton. Design and planning for the precise alignment of the highway at Edmonton including a possible need for a bypass if warranted will need to be addressed towards the latter end of the present five year forward program. A tentative figure at this stage for the proposed works is $5.4 million.

(2) (a) (b) The Minister for Land Transport recently approved the Bohle River bridges project at a cost of $5.5 million. Further duplication works on the northern approaches to Townsville will be considered, if justified by vehicle usage, and in relation to other priorities.

(3) The Federal commitment to upgrade the southern approach to Townsville will be met. As indicated in (1), the Queensland Department of Transport is reviewing major roads in Townsville and as a result Queensland may recommend a new highway alignment through Townsville. It is expected the new alignment will include University Road, which will be considered by the Minister for funding as part of the National Highway in Queensland.

(6) (a) (b) Due to the prolonged ``wet'' initial flood assessments are only now being received from Queensland and is therefore not possible to indicate how much of the Bruce Highway will be rehabilitated between Ayr and Townsville under the Natural Disaster Relief arrangements or will need to be funded through the Federal National Highway program. However remedial maintenance work was undertaken on the highway as soon as conditions permitted.
It is anticipated that the Ayr-Townsville section of the Bruce Highway will form part of a Queensland flood and damage assessment of the Bruce Highway expected shortly.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 11 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to reports on Tuesday, 12 March 1991, alleging Australian Airlines aircraft VH-TJJ flew illegally over water without sufficient life rafts:

(1) Knowing the aircraft was to fly over water, why did the captain not personally check the accessibility and number of life rafts before departure in accordance with the requirements of the flight manuals.

(2) Why did the captain allow the aircraft to depart without having the life rafts replaced, in direct contravention of the Air Navigation Orders relating to accessibility, type and number of emergency equipment carried.
(3) Was the captain an American pilot who was used to the United States system but not yet fully trained in Australian regulations.
(4) Was it part of a marketing strategy by Australian Airlines to put the life rafts out of the sight of the public in order to avoid reminding them of the dangers of flying.
(5) Will the Minister make available to the media and other interested parties, copies of the aircraft's maintenance releases for all over water flights for that day and the previous three weeks.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: On 14 March 1991 when responding to a Question Without Notice from Senator Powell, I advised the Senate that the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) was investigating the carriage of life rafts on Australian Airlines' aircraft. In its report to me, the CAA confirmed there was only one incident involving an Australian Airlines aircraft flying over water without the mandatory four life rafts stowed in the passenger compartment. This occurred on a flight between Melbourne and Perth, when an Australian Airlines' B737-400 aircraft, VH-TJK inadvertently carried two of the four life rafts in the cargo hold, with the remaining two life rafts correctly stowed in the passenger compartment.

The CAA concluded from its investigations that, apart from the VH-TJK incident, all other Australian Airlines aircraft, including VH-TJJ were operating legally at all times over water with the required number of life rafts stowed in their passenger compartment.
(1) &(2) As stated above, there was no illegal flight undertaken by VHTJJ over water on 12 March 1991 or any other date.

(3) VH-TJJ undertook three flights on 12 March 1991 with three different captains, none of whom were American. In relation to flights on 10 March 1991, VH-TJJ undertook two flights, namely Melbourne/Perth and Perth/Melbourne with an American captain. The American captain has been trained in the differences between the procedures he was used to and the procedures used in Australia, both the mandatory requirements of the regulations and the requirements of the airline. The regulations concerning carriage of life rafts in airlines in the USA and Australia are basically the same.

(4) No. On 1 March 1991, Australian Airlines introduced a new policy whereby two life rafts were to be re-located to the hold of the aircraft, in order to provide more hand luggage space in the passenger compartment. Procedures were set in place to return the two life rafts to the aircrafts' passenger compartments prior to each long over water flight. Following the incident on 10 March 1991 referred to above, the new policy was abolished and all life rafts are now re- installed in passenger compartments.
(5) No. No purpose would be served by making the maintenance releases available for VH-TJJ in view of the fact that the aircraft did not fly illegally over water.

(2) What is the breakdown of the participation rates of YHA recipients in DEET employment and training programs according to individual programs since the introduction of the YHA.
(3) What steps has DEET taken to ensure that each of its employment and training programs meet the needs and characteristics of homeless young people.
(4) What are the problems identified by DEET which are faced by young homeless people who either participate in, or seek to participate in, DEET employment and training programs.

(5) What has been the effect on the participation rates of young homeless people in many of DEET's employment and training programs arising from the fact that they are available only to people who have been unemployed for at least six months or, in many cases, at least one year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Information on the participation rate of recipients of the Young Homeless Allowance (YHA) in DEET employment and training programs is not currently collected. All YHA recipients are in receipt of the Job Search Allowance but the current information system does not disaggregate this information.

(3) DEET is primarily concerned about the education and labour market needs of clients such as literacy and numeracy needs and lack of skills. The needs of homeless young people are being considered and analysed at the local level and courses are designed to meet their employment education and training needs.

(4) The main problems facing young homeless people who participate in, or seek to participate in, DEET programs as identified by DEET are lack of competitiveness in the labour market brought about by low levels of work skills and experience. ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes; (a) General public information on the Australian Defence Force and the Department of Defence, and industry and general awareness of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO). (b) The Department aims to improve public awareness and understanding of defence issues and believes that this cannot be achieved by relying solely on the mass media. Extensive market research has identified the use of direct marketing for public information purposes as one of the major marketing tools available to Defence. The DSTO believes that direct marketing to selected industry and specialist groups plays a central role in the commercial exploitation of DSTO expertise and assets. (c) The primary method of direct marketing of general information about the Australian Defence Force and the Defence Department is the staging of Australian Defence Force Exhibitions at Royal Agricultural Shows around Australia which involve direct contact with the Australian Public. The former, of which six issues per year are sent to approximately 600 selected industry addresses, provides coverage of specific DSTO developments and projects of potential industry interest. The latter, of which approximately 5500 copies are distributed quarterly, is aimed at increasing general awareness of the DSTO in industry, the media, government, academic institutions and other special interest groups.

(a) the date the grant was made to the ACTU, Trades and Labour Council of WA, or a trade union; and

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Under arrangements agreed in the waterfront In-Principle Agreement (IPA) (Schedule 2, section 8), the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority has made three payments to the ACTU of $50 000-on 5 January 1990, 6 July 1990 and 9 November 1990.
(b) Under the IPA, the Commonwealth agreed to give financial assistance of up to S250 000 to supplement union research staff to assist the implementation of the Agreement.
Under the Agreement, the funds are to be used to finance the establishment and staffing of a combined stevedoring unions research unit. The functions of the Research Unit include the following:
(i) industrial research in relation to Award restructuring and the rationalisation of the number of Awards in the industry;

(ii) research and analysis concerning the development of the new classification structure for the Industry, including coordination and analysis of a skills audit, job redesign and the development of training curricula;
(iii) research and preparation of information and training materials for delegates and union members concerning the implementation of this Agreement and Award restructuring;
(iv) participation in training courses for union delegates and members explaining the charges;
(v) back-up research with respect to company-level agreements and implementation measures;
(vi) establishment of computerised information base, assessing databases;
(vii) other research and tasks as directed by the stevedoring unions, liaison with the Authority over research matters.
The IPA provides that a joint stevedoring union committee shall direct and oversee the work of the Research Unit.
